IV, §§ 2-126-2-130, 2-141-2-147, 2-161-2-165, 2-181-2-186, 2-191-2-196, 2-201-2-206, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1981, §§ 3.110-3.140; Ord. No. C-17-93, §§ 1(8-500-18-506), adopted 12-13-93; Ord. No. C-11-97, §§ 1(8-500-18-506), adopted 7-21-97; Ord. No. C-3-01, §§ 1(8-600-8-604), adopted 4-16-01; Ord. No. C-2-03, § 1, adopted 3-24-03; Ord. No. C-4-2003, § 1, adopted 9-8-03; Ord. No. C-8-03, § 1, adopted 10-27-03; Ord. No. C-3-2011, § 1, adopted 1-10-11; Ord. No. C-2-2014, § 1, adopted 4-21-14. 
Charter reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 3.12. 
Cross reference- Pension committee, § 2-283 et seq.; board of electrical examiners, § 7-146; housing commission, § 9-26 et seq.; economic development corporation, § 9-61 et seq.; historic districts and historic district commission, § 15-26 et seq.; historical commission, § 15-61 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 19-26 et seq.; city planning commission, § 21-26 et seq.; one-family residential review board, § 21-84; zoning board of appeals, § 34-661 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-126. - Continuation of existing boards, commissions and councils. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, all appointed boards, commissions and councils existing at the time of the adoption of the ordinances in this article shall be continued and the members serving thereon at such time shall remain in office for the duration of the term for which they were appointed. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-127. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "board, commission and council", in its plural and singular forms, shall mean and include all boards, commissions, councils, committees, corporations and authorities of the City of Farmington Hills established and appointed under this Code, resolutions adopted by city council, or applicable state laws or codes, and shall not include the city council. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-128. - General application. 
    The provisions in this division 1 of chapter 2, article IV shall apply to all boards, commissions and councils, unless otherwise indicated in this Code, resolutions adopted by city council, or applicable state laws or codes. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-129. - Purposes, authority and duties. 
    The assigned and designated purposes, authority and duties of each board, commission and council of the City of Farmington Hills are set forth in this Code, in resolutions adopted by city council, or in state laws or codes adopted by the State of Michigan. Boards, commissions and councils that have been established under this Code, under resolutions adopted by city council, or under state laws shall not engage in or undertake business, activities, actions or efforts beyond the scope of the purposes, authority and duties assigned or designated by this Code, City resolutions or state laws or codes. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-130. - Appointment of members; terms of office; period of service, voting. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in this Code or by law, the members of boards, commissions and councils, including alternates if any, shall be appointed by the mayor of Farmington Hills subject to approval by a majority vote of the members of the city council. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in this Code or by law, the appointed members of each board, commission and council shall hold office for three-year terms; provided, however, the initial appointments of members for the first board, commission and council and the initial appointments for any members subsequently added as a result of an increase in membership shall be for periods of one (1), two (2) and three (3) years, respectively, so as nearly as may be possible to provide for the staggered appointment of an equal number of members each year; thereafter each member to hold office for the full three-year term. 
(c)  Members of appointed boards, commissions and councils shall serve until a successor is appointed and seated, unless such member has been removed from office. 
(d)  Only the appointed members and alternates, when called to serve pursuant to section 2-131, are authorized to vote on matters coming before boards, commissions and councils. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-131. - Alternate members; terms of office; period of service. 
(a)  If this Code or applicable law permits the appointment of one (1) or more alternates to a board, commission or council, such alternate members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval by a majority vote of the members of the city council. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in this Code or by law, an appointed alternate shall hold office for three-year terms. 
(c)  Alternates shall serve until a successor is appointed and seated, unless such alternate has been removed from office. 
(d)  The chairperson of the board, commission or council shall call alternate members to serve on a rotating basis as a voting member in the absence of a regular member, and at all other times the alternate members may participate in all discussions but shall not have a vote and shall not count in determining the existence of a quorum. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-132. - Council liaisons; terms of office. 
    The mayor, subject to approval by majority vote of the members of council, may appoint a fellow member of council to serve as a liaison ("council liaison") to any board, commission and council. The term of a council liaison shall expire with his or her term on the city council. An appointed council liaison shall attend the meetings of and may participate in the deliberations and discussions of the board, commission or council, but shall not have a vote on any matter coming before the board, commission or council unless otherwise provided by law or this Code. The presence of a council liaison at a meeting shall not count toward the establishment of a quorum unless otherwise provided by law or this Code. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-133. - Staff liaisons. 
    The city manager, or his or her designee, may assign a member of the city administration to assist and serve as a liaison (referred to in this article as the "staff liaison") to any board, commission and council, unless otherwise provided by this Code. All staff liaisons shall serve at the pleasure and direction of the city manager. A designated staff liaison may attend the meetings of and provide information and input to the board, commission or council to which he or she is assigned, but shall not have a vote on any matter coming before the board, commission or council. The presence of a staff liaison at a meeting shall not count toward the establishment of a quorum. Additional members of the City administration may attend meetings of a board, commission and council if: 
(a)  Requested by the chair of the board, commission or council, and approved by the city manager or his or her designee; 
(b)  Directed to attend by the city manager or his or her designee; or 
(c)  Appointed as a voting or non-voting member of the board, commission or council under this Code, a resolution adopted by city council, or a state law or code. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-134. - Associate members. 
    A board, commission or council may appoint associate members (with the necessary skills or expertise) to serve on subcommittees working and advising on various matters consistent with the purposes, authority and duties of the board, commission or council. An associate member shall be appointed for a designated term not to exceed three (3) years, and if no term is designated then the appointment shall be for a term of one (1) year. Associate members may participate in all discussions but shall not have a vote and shall not count in determining the existence of a quorum. This section shall not apply to boards, commissions or councils established under or pursuant to state laws or state codes, unless specifically allowed under the applicable state laws or state codes. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-135. - Consultants. 
    A board, commission or council may recommend, through its assigned staff liaison, if any, that the city contract with consultants for services which the board, commission or council may require. If the recommendation involves services that will not exceed ten thousand one dollars ($10,001.00) per fiscal year of the city, the city manager shall consider and decide upon the recommendation. If the recommendation involves services that will exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per fiscal year of the city, the city manager shall submit the matter to city council for consideration. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-136. - Vacancies. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code or by law, any vacancy occurring in the membership of any board, commission or council, including alternates if any, shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term in the manner provided for original appointment. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-137. - Absences. 
    Three absences in the course of a calendar year may subject a member of any board, commission or council to removal from office. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-138. - Removal. 
    The removal of members, including alternates if any, of appointed boards, commissions and councils shall be in accordance with section 3.12 of the charter and any otherwise applicable state laws and city ordinances, policies and resolutions. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-139. - Compensation. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code or any otherwise applicable state law, all members and alternates of appointed boards, commissions, committees, councils, corporations and authorities of the city shall serve without compensation. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-140. - Officers; meetings; quorum. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in this Code or by law, each board, commission and council shall conduct the election of a chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary from among its members and the terms of office for each such position shall be one (1) year with eligibility for reelection; provided, however, a member shall not be eligible to serve more than two (2) successive terms as chairperson. The chairperson shall preside at all meetings, and in his or her absence, the co-chair, if any, shall preside, or if no co-chair, then the vice-chair shall preside. A member who presides over a meeting retains his or her status as a voting member. Each board, commission and council may create and fill such other offices as it may deem necessary or expedient. The annual election of officers shall occur within thirty (30) days after the annual appointments or re-appointments of members to the board, commission, committee council, corporation or authority. Any member serving a term as an elected officer at the time of enactment of the ordinance establishing the terms and term limitations set forth in this section, which current term would not otherwise be permitted under this section, shall be permitted to complete his or her current term in the office. 
(b)  Each board, commission and council shall meet no less than one (1) time per year and as regularly as necessary to conduct business, and, in coordination with its designated staff liaison if any, shall keep a record of its minutes, resolutions, transactions, findings, determinations, documents and other materials. 
(c)  In order to avoid undertaking business or activities beyond the scope of the purposes, authority and duties assigned by this Code or by law, and to promote orderly and efficient meetings, each meeting of appointed boards, commissions and councils shall have an agenda prepared in advance of the meeting which shall be distributed to all members and liaisons. If a staff liaison has been appointed, the agenda shall be prepared by the staff liaison with input from the chair and vice-chair. Otherwise, the agenda shall be prepared by the chair and vice-chair. Other members of the board, commission or council may ask for items to be included on an agenda through the chair or vice-chair, or by a majority vote of the membership. 
(d)  The presence of a number of voting members equaling a majority of the appointed regular membership of the board, commission or council shall constitute a quorum for purposes of conducting business (i.e., open or vacant seats shall not count in determining the existence of a quorum and alternate members called by the chairperson to serve at a meeting shall count in determining the existence of a quorum). 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-141. - Bylaws. 
    Each appointed board, commission and council shall, with the assistance of its staff liaison, if any, and the city attorney, adopt bylaws for the transaction of business and to identify the duties and responsibilities of the officers elected under section 2-140. The bylaws also shall include the adoption of rules of order and procedures for the conduct of meetings and shall provide that they may be amended at a duly constituted meeting of the board, commission or council by the affirmative vote of a two-thirds (?) majority of the members. The bylaws may provide for the establishment of any subcommittees and associate members, subject to section 2-134. The bylaws shall be consistent with, and shall not conflict with or deviate from any of the provisions in this article, this Code, or applicable laws. The bylaws shall be reviewed by each board, commission, committee and council on a regular basis to ensure that they remain consistent with existing laws, ordinances and practice. The bylaws and any amendments thereto, prior to becoming effective, shall be submitted to city council for review and approval. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-142. - Budget. 
    If a board, commission or council of the city has been assigned a budget by city council, it shall work with its designated staff liaison, if any, to develop and submit an annual budget request to city council for its approval. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-143. - Reporting to city council. 
    Each board, commission and council shall, with the assistance of its staff liaison, if any, prepare a written report to city council at least one (1) time in each calendar year and, if requested by the mayor or city council, shall present said report at a meeting of city council. In addition to any other information that may be required by law, the reports shall inform and advise city council on the number of meetings held, the activities and items of business that have been and are being undertaken by the board, commission or council, and any recommendations or advice the board, commission or council may have concerning city policy matters relating to the purposes, authority and duties of the board, commission or council. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-144. - Open meetings act and freedom of information act. 
    All appointed boards, commissions and councils shall comply, in all respects, with the Michigan Open Meetings Act and Freedom of Information Act. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-145-2-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMISSION ON CHILDREN, YOUTH, AND FAMILIES 

Sec. 2-151. - Establishment; purposes. 
    There is established in cooperation with the City of Farmington a commission on children, youth, and families to encourage an environment where children, youth, and families are happy, healthy, educated, safe and have the opportunity to reach their full potential. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-152. - Purposes, authority and duties. 
    The commission is charged with the authority and responsibility of making recommendations to the cities concerning the needs of children, youth and families of the cities and the appropriate means by which public and private agencies in cooperation with volunteer efforts may address such needs. The commission may establish a community volunteer center to disseminate information and answer questions about community agencies and volunteer opportunities. It may develop and make available a resource information base in cooperation with public and private agencies. It may develop a coalition of community leaders to promote volunteerism among its citizens, businesses and their employees and other agencies. It may also promote and encourage the implementation of any program consistent with the purpose for which the commission is established including, but not limited to, Family Day in the Park, Family Nights at Costick Center and Holiday Tree Lighting. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-153. - Members; appointment; quorum. 
    The commission shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the general citizens of the cities, the students of the Farmington area schools, the clergy, the school districts, the juvenile division and/or friend of the court agency of the judiciary, local business, regional and national business, the medical professions, local volunteer agencies and regional volunteer agencies. At least one (1) regular member of the commission shall be an adult resident of the City of Farmington Hills. Nine (9) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by City of Farmington Hills. Two (2) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-154. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-155-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - MAYOR'S YOUTH COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-161. - Establishment; purposes. 
    There is established a mayor's youth council, whose mission is to serve as a conduit between the local governments and their younger constituents. Voice will be given to teenagers to bring all issues, great and small, to the forefront. Conversely, the youth council will bring the government's voice to teenagers, showing all the opportunities to enrich the teenagers of Farmington Hills/Farmington. Bringing youth and the government together gives both more power to better the community. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-162. - Purposes, authority and duties. 
    The youth council is charged with the authority and responsibility of making recommendations to the cities concerning the needs and concerns of youth and the community and the appropriate means by which public and private agencies in cooperation with volunteer efforts may address such needs and concerns. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-163. - Members; appointment. 
    The youth council shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members who shall be selected from the high school age students who reside in Farmington Hills and Farmington. Nine (9) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington Hills. Two (2) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington. The youth council may appoint high school students as associate members to serve on committees advising it on various matters. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-164. - Terms of office. 
    Members of the youth council shall hold office for a one-year term and until their successors are appointed and qualified; however, members may serve for more than one (1) term. Appointments shall be made to coincide with the academic calendar in order to facilitate greatest student involvement. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-165. - Absences. 
    Three (3) unexcused absences in the course of a term shall subject a member to removal from office in the sole discretion of the mayor. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-166. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the council. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-167-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - COMMISSION ON AGING 

Sec. 2-171. - Establishment; purposes. 
    The City of Farmington Hills established the Farmington Area Commission on Aging by resolution on March 14, 1977, in cooperation with the City of Farmington. The city hereby ratifies and continues the existence of the commission on aging under this Code, in continued cooperation with the City of Farmington, as a duly organized and established city commission having the purposes of promoting the well-being and dignity of older adults and supporting the betterment of daily living for older adults in the cities of Farmington Hills and Farmington. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-172. - Purposes, authority and duties. 
    The commission on aging is charged with the authority and responsibility of making recommendations to the cities concerning the needs of older adults in the cities and the appropriate means by which public and private agencies in cooperation with volunteer efforts may address such needs. The commission may disseminate information and answer questions about community agencies and volunteer opportunities. It may develop and make available a resource and/or service information base. It may also promote and encourage the implementation of any program consistent with the purpose for which the commission is established including, but not limited to, Community for a Lifetime, Volunteer Award Program, Farmington Area Senior Services Directory. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-173. - Members; appointment. 
    The commission on aging shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the general citizens of the cities, the clergy, local business, regional and national business, the medical professions, local volunteer agencies and regional volunteer agencies. Nine (9) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington Hills. Two (2) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington. The city's senior adult program supervisor shall serve as the staff liaison to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-174. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-175-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITIZEN CORPS COUNCIL FOR EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS 

Sec. 2-181. - Establishment; purpose. 
    There is established a citizen corps council for emergency preparedness having the purposes of supporting and enhancing the efforts of local public safety organizations in helping ensure that residents and business owners in Farmington Hills and Farmington have the information, education, and skills necessary to protect themselves, their families, homes, and businesses in the event of a local emergency. The citizen corps council for emergency preparedness may also be referred to as the "EPC" or "Emergency Preparedness Commission." 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-182. - Authority, purposes and duties. 
    The citizen corps council for emergency preparedness is charged with the authority and responsibility of making recommendations to the two (2) cities concerning public education on safety, helping citizens take an active role in protecting themselves from harm, teaching citizens what to do in the event of a crisis, and providing citizens with the skills and abilities to make their families, homes and communities safer from the threats of terrorism, crime, and disaster. The citizen corps council may develop and make available a resource and/or service information base. It may also coordinate with other agencies (such as the police and fire department), promote and encourage the implementation of any program consistent with the purpose for which the commission is established including but not limited to CPR, first aid, and other emergency situation training for taking care of the family. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-183. - Members; appointment. 
    The EPC shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the general citizens of the cities, subdivision and condominium homeowners associations, local business, judiciary, medical professions, first aid specialists, hospitals, schools, community organizations, radio and television communications, and emergency aid agencies. Nine (9) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington Hills. Two (2) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington. The cities' fire chief, police chief, public safety director and clerks, or their designated officer in charge of emergency preparedness issues, shall serve as liaisons to the EPC. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-184. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the council. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-185-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - COMMISSION ON COMMUNITY HEALTH 

Sec. 2-201. - Establishment; purposes. 
    There is established in cooperation with the City of Farmington a commission on community health having the purposes of supporting and encouraging an environment where residents have access to quality health services and wellness programs, and to the information, education, and resources necessary to promote physical and mental health and wellbeing. The commission's purpose is to achieve a community-wide collaboration and partnership of organizations and individuals to work together to identify and develop new and innovative programs, utilize existing programs, and locate and capture funding to assist in building a healthier community. The commission on community health may also be referred to as the "community health commission." 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-202. - Authority, purposes and duties. 
    The commission on community health is charged with the authority and responsibility of making recommendations to the cities concerning community health matters and the appropriate means by which public and private agencies, in cooperation with community volunteers and health care professionals, may increase public awareness and utilization of new and available programs and resources to improve the overall health and wellness of the community and motivate individuals to make healthy behavioral changes. The commission may establish and make available information dissemination programs to provide information and answer questions about public health and wellness issues and the local programs available to respond to health-related concerns. It may engage in multisector collaborations with residents, community stakeholders, healthcare professionals and others to identify and implement innovative approaches, promote existing programs, and explore funding opportunities to encourage improvements in health and quality of life throughout the community. It may also promote and encourage the implementation and utilization of any program consistent with the purpose for which the commission is established including, but not limited to, the F2H Fit Challenge and Farmington SAFE programs. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-203. - Members; appointment. 
    The commission shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the general citizens of the city, the students of the Farmington area schools, the clergy, the school districts, local businesses, medical professions, hospitals, community organizations, and local and regional volunteer agencies. Nine (9) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington Hills. Two (2) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the City of Farmington. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-204. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-205-2-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-211. - Establishment; purposes. 
    The City of Farmington Hills established the beautification commission by resolution of the city council on or about July 22, 1985. The city hereby ratifies and continues the existence of the beautification commission under this Code as a duly organized and established city commission having the purposes of promoting and encouraging city-wide aesthetic improvements and beautification in order to maintain the character, aesthetic appeal and image of our community and preserve the kind of quality of life that Farmington Hills represents. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-212. - Authority, purposes and duties. 
    The beautification commission is charged with the purposes, authority and duties of advising the Farmington Hills City Council about beautification and environmental concerns of the city, promoting and publicizing beautification and environmental projects in the city, and encouraging and acknowledging projects of beautification and environmental improvement in the city through: 
(a)  Research and study, bringing to the attention of city council areas of the city in need of beautification and/or environmental attention; 
(b)  Recommendations, advising council of the ways and means of improvement in these areas and to recommend high standards of community development; 
(c)  Local and area media, promoting beautification and environmental projects undertaken by the commission, the city, businesses, groups and individuals; and 
(d)  Letters, public recognition, the press and electronic media, commending groups, businesses and individuals for their community development projects or programs that result in beautification and environmental improvement. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-213. - Members. 
    The beautification commission shall consist of nine (9) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the residents of the city and businesses located within the city. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-214. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-215-2-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - FARMINGTON AREA ARTS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-221. - Establishment; purposes. 
    The City of Farmington Hills established the Farmington Area Arts Commission in the early 1970s, in cooperation with the City of Farmington. The city hereby ratifies and continues the existence of the Farmington Area Arts Commission under this Code, in continued cooperation with the City of Farmington, as a duly organized and established city commission having the purposes of presenting a unified voice to explore needs, foster communication and promote activities of art and culture in the cities of Farmington Hills and Farmington. The Farmington Area Arts Commission may also be referred to as the "FAAC." 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-222. - Purposes, authority and duties. 
    The FAAC is charged with the authority and responsibility of providing an encouraging environment that stimulates performing and creative artists to study and present their talents. This commission will work toward that end by defining and creating appropriate programs to implement artistic and cultural activities that touch many areas of our lives, such as: music, theater, dance, education institutions, visual arts, literature and letters, architecture and architectural landscaping, museums, and allied arts and crafts. The FAAC will also encourage public interest in the cultural heritage of the community. It will receive and disburse funds from the City of Farmington Hills, the City of Farmington, and the Michigan State Council of the Arts. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-223. - Members; appointment. 
    The FAAC shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the general citizens of the cities and persons in the cities who are representative of the fields of the performing and creative arts. Nine (9) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the mayor of Farmington Hills subject to the approval by a majority vote of the members of the Farmington Hills Council. Two (2) regular members and one (1) alternate member shall be appointed by the mayor of Farmington subject to approval by a majority vote of the members of the Farmington Council. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-224. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-225-2-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - COMMISSION TO INCREASE VOTER PARTICIPATION 

Sec. 2-231. - Establishment; purposes. 
    The City of Farmington Hills established the committee to increase voter participation by motion of the city council on April 26, 1976. The city hereby ratifies and continues the existence of this committee under this Code as a duly organized and established city commission having the name commission to increase voter participation and the purposes set forth below. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-232. - Authority, purposes and duties. 
    The commission to increase voter participation is charged with the purposes, authority and duties of stimulating and improving voter participation in all elections and increasing the quality and quantity of publicity and information regarding such elections. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-233. - Members. 
    The commission to increase voter participation shall consist of eleven (11) regular members and two (2) alternate members, who shall represent, insofar as possible, the residents of the city and businesses located within the city. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-234. - Other applicable ordinances. 
    Without limitation, refer to chapter 2, article IV, division 1 of this Code for additional city ordinances that may be applicable to the commission. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-235-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - OTHER BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COUNCILS 

Sec. 2-241. - Established under other ordinances or laws. 
    The boards, commissions, committees, councils, authorities and corporations listed below have been established or recognized by the City of Farmington Hills under and pursuant to the separate chapters of this Code, resolutions of the city council and/or the state laws set forth below, and such boards, commissions, committees, councils, authorities and corporations shall be subject to division 1 of this article to the extent said division is not contrary to or inconsistent with such other provisions of this Code, resolutions of the city council or the state laws governing them: 
(a)  Animal review board (City Code, chapter 6, article III, dangerous animals) 
(b)  Board of review (City Charter, article III, section 3.10; Public Act 279 of 1909, MCL 117.3(a)) 
(c)  Brownfield redevelopment authority (City council resolution R-20-00; Public Act 381 of 1996, MCL 125.2651, et seq.) 
(d)  Construction board of appeals (City Code, chapter 7, article II, state construction codes; Public Act 230 of 1972, MCL 125.1501, et seq.) 
(e)  Economic development corporation (City council resolution, July 16, 1979 Approving Articles of Incorporation; Public Act 338 of 1974) 
(f)  Employee retirement board (City Code, chapter 2, article V, employee benefits) 
(g)  Farmington Community Library Board (Public Act 24 of 1989, MCL 397.171, et seq.) 
(h)  Fire Code board of appeals (City Code, chapter 12, article II, Fire Code) 
(i)  Grand River Corridor Improvement Authority (City council resolution R-155-11; Public Act 280 of 2005, MCL 125.2871, et seq.) 
(j)  Historic district commission (City Code, chapter 15, article II, Historic districts and historic districts commission; Public Act 169 of 1970, MCL 399.201 et seq.) 
(k)  Historical commission (City Code, chapter 15, article III, historical commission) 
(l)  Housing commission (City Code, chapter 9, article II, housing commission) 
(m)  Housing rehabilitation loan board (Federal Community Development Block Grant Housing Rehabilitation Assistance Guidelines) 
(n)  Multicultural multiracial community council (City council resolutions R-19-97, R-67-96, and R-58-94) 
(o)  One-family residential review board, formerly the single-family residential review board (City Code, chapter 21, article IV, one-family construction review) 
(p)  Parks and recreation commission (City Code, chapter 19, article II, parks and recreation commission) 
(q)  Planning commission (City Code, chapter 21, article II, city planning commission; Public Act 33 of 2008, MCL 125.3801, et seq.)) 
(r)  Property Maintenance Code board of appeals (City Code, chapter 7, article III, Property Maintenance Code) 
(s)  Public access promotion committee (City council resolution, 12-82-322, 2011 agreement for multi-jurisdictional administration of a cable television franchise (as amended and restated), and bylaws of SWOCC (as amended and restated)) 
(t)  Zoning board of appeals (City Code, chapter 34, zoning; Public Act 110 of 2006, MCL 125.3101, et seq.) 
Division 1, sections 2-131, 2-132, 2-133, 2-134, 2-140(b), 2-141 and 2-143 of this article shall not apply to the animal review board, board of review, construction board of appeals, Farmington Community Library Board, Fire Code board of appeals, Property Maintenance Code board of appeals, and any advisory boards, councils or committees established by the city administration. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Sec. 2-242. - Discontinued boards, commissions and councils. 
    Any boards, commissions, committees, councils, authorities and corporations not set forth in this article and not otherwise established in this Code are hereby discontinued and dissolved, and any resolutions, motions or other actions of the city to establish them are hereby repealed in their entirety. This section does not apply to any advisory boards, councils or committees established by the city administration, provided such boards, councils and committees have been authorized by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. C-4-2017, § 1, 5-22-17 ) 
Secs. 2-243-2-250. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

Sec. 2-261. - Retirement system effective date; continuation; purpose. 
    The City of Farmington Hills Employees Retirement System established effective January 1, 1966, as amended, is continued for the purpose of providing retirement income to qualifying employees and former employees, and survivor income to their qualifying beneficiaries. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-262. - Short title; application; effective date of restatement. 
(a)  This division may be cited as the City of Farmington Hills Retirement Ordinance. 
(b)  This restatement will apply to individuals employed by the city on and after July 1, 2013. The retirement rights of an individual whose city employment terminated before July 1, 2013, will be governed by the provisions of the retirement system in effect on the date the individual last terminated employment. 
(c)  This division was previously restated with a prior effective date of July 1, 2005, or such other date specified by the city council or charter when that restatement of this division was enacted. 
(d)  This restatement to interpret and clarify this division for proper implementation shall be put into effect as of July 1, 2013, upon final passage by the city council of the City of Farmington Hills with an effective date of July 1, 2013, or such other date specified by the city council or charter when this division is enacted. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-263, 2-264. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-265. - Gender references. 
    Any references in this document to one (1) gender, whether male or female, should be understood to include the other gender as well. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-266-2-269. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-270. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
(a)  Accumulated member contributions means the balance in a member's individual account in the reserve for member contributions, including accumulated interest on member contributions. 
(b)  Actuarially equivalent means that the two (2) benefits being compared have equal actuarial present values. Actuarial equivalents shall be calculated using assumptions adopted by resolution of the retirement board. 
(c)  Beneficiary means an individual who is being paid or who has entitlement to the future payment of a pension on account of a reason other than the individual's membership in the retirement system. The beneficiary is required to have an "insurable interest" in the life of the member. 
(d)  City means the City of Farmington Hills, State of Michigan, and its various offices, boards, agencies and departments. 
(e)  Compensation means the salary or wages paid an employee for personal services rendered the city while a member of the retirement system. Salary and wages shall include: base pay; and pay for periods of absence from work by reason of vacation, holiday, and sickness. For members of all benefit groups, compensation shall include an amount equal to the applicable longevity pay percentage multiplied by base pay at the time of payment of longevity, except for in the fiscal year the employee retires if the employee retires before receiving longevity pay for that fiscal year, then, for the purpose of calculating the final average compensation only, longevity is not pro-rated, but is calculated on the base pay as of July 1 st of that fiscal year. The applicable longevity payment will be the longevity payment in effect for each fiscal year without interpolation in accordance with the longevity seniority schedule for each benefit group. For members of Benefit Groups C, D, F and P only, compensation shall include lump sum holiday pay. For members of Benefit Group F compensation shall also include four-ten premium pay. Compensation shall not include any remuneration or reimbursement not specifically stated to be included: such as, remuneration for overtime services, allowances for clothing, equipment, cleaning and travel; reimbursement of expenses; bonuses; termination pay; severance pay; payments in consideration of unused vacation and sick leave; the value of any fringe benefit. 
(f)  Deferred retirement means that if a member terminates employment after being vested but prior to eligibility for normal or early retirement and leaves all accumulated contributions in the retirement system, then the vested former member is eligible for a pension beginning at an age and service level established by contract or policy. "Vested former member" means a former member who terminated employment after attaining the service requirement for vesting but prior to eligibility for normal or early retirement and leaves all accumulated contributions in the retirement system. 
(g)  Defined contribution plan means the City of Farmington Hills 401(a) defined contribution pension program as established by the city. 
(h)  Early retirement means that a member is eligible for a reduced pension benefit at an age and service level established by contract or policy. 
(i)  Final average compensation means the average of the monthly rate of compensation paid a member as of the three (3) consecutive July 1sts producing the highest average contained within the ten (10) years of credited service immediately preceding the member's last termination of employment with the city. 
(j)  Firefighter means a full-time employee of the department of public safety, fire division, with the rank of firefighter or higher. 
(k)  Insurable interest. As used in this retirement ordinance, the only persons considered to have an "insurable interest" in the life of an individual are the individual's legal spouse, a natural or adopted child of the individual, a parent of the individual and a sibling of the individual; and, when applicable, an individual's former spouse may have an insurable interest, if there is an appropriate entered eligible domestic relations order (EDRO), or domestic relations order (DRO) ordering such. 
(l)  Member means any person who is included in the membership of the city's defined benefit retirement system. 
(m)  Normal retirement means a retirement as provided at section 2-231 wherein a member is eligible for an unreduced pension benefit at an age and service level established by contract or policy. 
(n)  Paid callback firefighter is a person who is employed on an "on call" basis with the department of public safety, fire division, without regularly scheduled full-time employee hours and is not eligible for fringe benefits afforded career firefighters. 
(o)  Part-time employees are employees hired on a part-time basis and shall not work more than an average of twenty-nine (29) hours per week calculated over a twelve-month time frame. 
(p)  Pension means a series of monthly payments by the retirement system. Payment may be for a temporary period or throughout the future life of a retired member or beneficiary. 
(q)  Police officer means an employee of the department of public safety, police division, with rank of patrol officer or higher. 
(r)  Retired member means an individual who is being paid a pension on account of the individual's membership in the defined benefit retirement system. 
(s)  Retirement system means the City of Farmington Hills Employees Retirement System, a defined benefit plan, as established pursuant to article V, division 2 of the Code of Ordinances of the city. 
(t)  Service means personal service rendered the city while a member of the retirement system and qualifying military service pursuant to section 2-300. 
(u)  Temporary employees are employees hired on a temporary basis for a period not to exceed four (4) consecutive months or a total of six (6) months in a calendar year. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-271-2-279. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-280. - Membership in retirement system. 
    A person who is employed by the city in an included position is a member of the retirement system. Included positions are: 
    Positions held by all individuals who are employed by the city, its offices, boards, agencies or departments, in a permanent position unless employed in an excluded position enumerated in section 2-281. For purposes of this section, a permanent position is defined as a position on a regular rather than a temporary or seasonal basis. In case of doubt, the retirement board shall decide who is a member. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-281. - Excluded positions. 
    Excluded positions are: 
(a)  Positions filled by part-time or temporary employees. 
(b)  Positions which are compensated on a basis not subject to the withholding of federal income taxes or FICA taxes by the city or to existing fringe benefits provided by the city. 
(c)  Any position held by a retired member. 
(d)  Paid call back firefighters. 
(e)  Positions, other than judgeships, for which less than half (1/2) the public compensation is paid by the city. 
(f)  Any position held by a person who is included by law, by action of the city council, by collective bargaining agreement or by individual employment agreement in any other pension or retirement plan by reason of the compensation paid by the city, except the Federal Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance Program. 
(g)  Positions of city manager or department director, if the person has elected, with consent of the city council, not to be a member. Thereafter, the city council may provide an option for the person to become a member of the retirement system as of such date and subject to such terms and conditions as established by city council resolution or as contained in the person's employment agreement, provided however, that such terms and conditions shall be in accordance with applicable law. 
(h)  Employees of Benefit Groups A, E or G that are hired on or after July 1, 2006, employees of Benefit Group D that are hired on or after January 1, 2007, employees of Benefit Group T that are hired on or after January 1, 2008, and employees of Benefit Group J that are hired on or after September 1, 2015. In lieu of membership in the retirement system, such employees shall participate in the defined contribution plan. Contribution rates in the defined contribution plan for the employer and employee will be calculated on base pay, as that term is defined in the defined contribution plan document. Employees will contribute five (5) percent of base pay and the city/court will contribute ten (10) percent of the employee's base pay into the defined contribution plan. Employees shall be fifty (50) percent vested in the city's/court's contributions to the defined contribution plan after three (3) full years of employment with the city/court, seventy-five (75) percent vested after five (5) full years of employment, and one hundred (100) percent vested after seven (7) full years of employment. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13; Ord. No. C-8-2015, § 1 , 8-10-15) 
Sec. 2-282. - Termination of membership. 
(a)  An individual shall cease to be a member of the retirement system upon termination of employment or upon becoming employed in an excluded position. Upon reemployment by the city in an included position entitling the employee to membership, the individual shall again become a member. 
(b)  A former employee from Benefit Groups A, D, E, G & T who withdrew his or her accumulated member contributions prior to reemployment, shall participate in the defined contribution plan in lieu of membership in the retirement system (as provided in subsection 2-281(h)). 
(c)  Except for members of Benefit Groups C, F and P, an individual whose retirement system membership terminates before retirement shall not qualify for any of the medical benefits provided by the city and the retirement system, to individuals whose retirement system membership continued until retirement. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13)

(a)  The person's accumulated member contributions have not been refunded; and 
(b)  The person satisfies the service requirement that applies to the person's benefit group.

    A vested former member shall not receive credited service while absent from city employment. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-286-2-289. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-290. - Credited service-Earned. 
    Service rendered by a member shall be credited to the member's individual credited service account in accordance with rules the retirement board shall prescribe. Service shall be in calendar months. For employees whose regular work schedule is based on eight-hour days and forty (40) hours a week, ten (10) or more days of paid service during a calendar month will qualify a member for credited service for that calendar month. For employees whose regular work schedule is based on ten-hour days and forty (40) hours a week, eight (8) or more days of paid service during a calendar month will qualify a member for credited service for that calendar month. For employees whose regular work schedule is based on forty-eight (48) hours a week, seven (7) or more days of paid service during a calendar month will qualify a member for credited service for that calendar month. No credit will be given to a member for a calendar month during which the member has fewer than the minimum qualified days of paid service as provided herein. In no case shall a member receive more than one (1) year of credited service for all service rendered by the member during any one (1) calendar year. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-291. - Same-Forfeiture. 
    Credited service shall be forfeited if an individual who is not a retired member receives a refund of his or her accumulated member contributions upon termination of service. Credited service shall also be forfeited if an individual who is not a retired member or vested former member has a break in membership of five (5) years or more, at which time all accumulated member contributions will be refunded. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-292. - Same-Reinstatement. 
    A member may have forfeited credited service restored upon satisfaction of each of the following conditions: 
(a)  The retirement system is paid the total amount of accumulated member contributions previously withdrawn by the member, if any, plus compound interest at the rate(s) determined by the retirement board from the date(s) of withdrawal to the date(s) of repayment; and 
(b)  The repayment is initiated and completed within the time periods established by the retirement board. 
    Service credit earned prior to the member's most recent break in membership of five (5) years or more shall not be restored. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-293-2-299. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-300. - Intervening military service-Conditions for credited service. 
    A member who leaves the employ of the city to enter any armed service of the United States during time of war, period of compulsory military service, or period of national emergency recognized by the city council shall be entitled to credited service for periods of active duty if each of the following conditions are satisfied: 
(a)  The individual is reemployed by the city within the time period required by the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (P.L. 103-353), as amended; 
(b)  The individual becomes a member and pays the retirement system the total amount of accumulated member contributions previously withdrawn, plus compound interest from the date of withdrawal to the dates of repayment; 
(c)  No more than five (5) years of credited service shall be granted on account of all military service of the member; and 
(d)  Credited service shall not be granted for periods of military service which are or could be used for obtaining or increasing a benefit from another retirement plan, except for service that is or would be credited under the federal government for service in the reserves. 
    In case of doubt as to the period to be credited to a member, the retirement board shall have the final power to determine such question. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-301-2-309. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-310. - Benefit groups-Composition. 
    The following benefit groups are designated for the purpose of determining benefit eligibility conditions, benefit amounts, and member contribution rates, as well as other non-uniform provisions for all employees that are included in the membership in the retirement system. 
(a)  Benefit Group A (AFSCME). All members who are covered by the AFSCME collective bargaining agreement. 
(b)  Benefit Group C (Police Command). All members who are full-time sworn police officers and who are not in Benefit Group P (Police Officer). 
(c)  Benefit Group D (Dispatcher). All members who are full-time police dispatchers. 
(d)  Benefit Group E (Executive). All members who are designated as full-time executive employees, including the city manager, assistant city managers, the assistant to the city manager, department heads, all judges, the court administrator and deputy court administrator of the 47th District Court. 
(e)  Benefit Group F (Fire). All members who are full-time firefighters. 
(f)  Benefit Group G (General-Exempt). All members not included in another benefit group. 
(g)  Benefit Group J (Court). All members who are full-time employees of the 47th District Court excluding the judges, the court administrator and the deputy court administrator. 
(h)  Benefit Group P (Police Officer). All members who hold the full-time rank of police officer. 
(i)  Benefit Group T (Teamsters). All members who are covered by the Teamsters collective bargaining agreement. 
    In case of doubt, the retirement board shall determine the benefit group(s) that apply to a member. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13; Ord. No. C-8-2015, § 2 , 8-10-15) 
Sec. 2-311. - Benefit groups-Effect on retirement eligibility. 
    Benefit eligibility conditions shall be those applicable to the member's benefit group at time of termination of employment. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-312. - Benefit groups-Effect on pension amount. 
    If a retiring individual has credited service with more than one (1) benefit group, then the individual's pension will be as follows: 
(1)  If the individual has three (3) or more years of service with the benefit group the individual was in at termination of employment and has met the retirement eligibility requirements for the benefit group, the pension shall be calculated based on the provisions of that benefit group. 
(2)  If the individual does not satisfy the requirements of the preceding paragraph, then the amount of the individual's pension shall be the sum of the amounts for each benefit group the individual has service with. The amount for each benefit group the individual has service with shall be determined as follows: 
a.  Determine the amount of pension that would apply if the individual's total credited service in force had been earned with the first benefit group (sections 2-330 and 2-331). 
b.  Determine the proportion of the individual's total credited service that was earned with that benefit group. 
c.  Multiply (a) by (b). This is the pension amount attributable to service with the specified benefit group. 
d.  Repeat steps (a), (b) and (c) for each other benefit group the individual has service with. 
e.  Add the results from step (c) for each benefit group the individual has service with. This sum is the amount of the pension under optional form of payment SL. 
    These calculations shall be based upon the retirement system provisions in effect at the time the individual terminates membership. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-313-2-319. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-320. - Age retirement-Conditions. 
    A member or vested former member may retire with a normal or early retirement pension upon satisfaction of each of the following requirements: 
(a)  A written application for retirement, in the form prescribed by the retirement board, has been filed with the retirement system; 
(b)  Employment is terminated prior to the effective date of retirement; and 
(c)  The member meets the applicable age and/or service requirements for retirement. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-321. - Normal retirement-Age and service requirements. 
    The age and service requirements for normal retirement are: 
(a)  Benefit Groups A, D, E, G, J and T. The member has attained age sixty (60) with eight (8) years of service, or the member has attained age fifty-five (55) and the sum of the member's years of age and years of service is greater than or equal to eighty (80). 
(b)  Benefit Group P. For employees hired prior to January 1, 2008, the member has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service earned while employed by the city as a police officer. For employees hired on or after January 1, 2008, the member has attained age fifty (50) years and has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service earned while employed by the city as a police officer. For purposes of meeting the service eligibility requirements of this subsection, credited service earned while the member was a police cadet shall not be considered. 
(c)  Benefit Group C. The member has attained age fifty (50) years and has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service earned while employed by the city as a police officer (a member who has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service and has attained the age of forty-eight (48), may elect to purchase up to two (2) years of service at the members cost to be eligible for normal retirement) or the member has thirty (30) or more years of credited service with the city regardless of age, provided the member has twenty-five (25) years or more of service while employed by the city as a police officer. For purposes of meeting the service eligibility requirements of this subsection, credited service earned while the member was a police cadet shall not be considered. 
(d)  Benefit Group F. For employees hired prior to July 1, 2008, the member has twenty-five (25) years or more of credited service, earned while employed by the city as a firefighter, regardless of age. For employees hired on or after July 1, 2008, the member has attained age fifty (50) years and has twenty-five (25) or more years of credited service earned while employed by the city as a firefighter, 
    Upon retirement as provided in this section, a member shall be paid a pension computed according to the provisions of section 2-330. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Sec. 2-322. - Normal retirement-Vested former member. 
(a)  A vested former member may retire upon satisfying the age and service credit retirement conditions that applied to the person's benefit group when the member was last employed by the city. 
(b)  Withdrawal of accumulated member contributions shall result in the loss of credited service and shall constitute forfeiture of all rights to any pension provided by the retirement system. 
(c)  Upon retirement as provided in this section a vested former member shall be paid a pension computed according to the provisions of the retirement ordinance in effect for the member on the date the former member ceased to be an employee. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13) 
Secs. 2-323-2-329. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-330. - Normal retirement-Amount of pension. 
    The annual benefit amount under form of payment SL (straight life) is determined as follows: 
(a)  Benefit Group A. The normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and eight-tenths (2.8) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed seventy-five (75) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(b)  Benefit Groups G, J and T. The normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and eight-tenths (2.8) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed eighty (80) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(c)  Benefit Groups C and E. The normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of three (3.0) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed eighty (80) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(d)  Benefit Group D. 
(1)  Until the retiree attains age sixty-seven (67), the normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and sixty-five-hundredths (2.65) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed seventy (70) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(2)  At age sixty-seven (67), the normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and three hundred seventy-five thousandths (2.375) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed seventy (70) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(e)  Benefit Group F. 
(1)  For employees hired prior to July 1, 2008, the normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and eight-tenths (2.8) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed seventy-five (75) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(2)  For employees hired on or after July 1, 2008, the normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and one-quarter (2.25) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed sixty (60) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(f)  Benefit Group P. 
(1)  For employees hired prior to January 1, 2008, the normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and eight-tenths (2.8) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed seventy-five (75) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
(2)  For employees hired on or after January 1, 2008, the normal retirement benefit amount will be the member's final average compensation multiplied by the sum of two and one-quarter (2.25) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service not in excess of twenty-five (25) years, and one (1) percent times years and fraction of a year of credited service in excess of twenty-five (25) years, with the total benefit not to exceed sixty (60) percent of the member's final average compensation. 
    If the member or vested former member has credited service with more than one (1) benefit group, the pension amount shall be computed in accordance with the provisions of section 2-312. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13)

The member has attained age fifty (50) years and has fifteen (15) or more years of credited service, served while employed by the city as a sworn police officer, or the member is less than the age of fifty (50) years and has attained twenty-five (25) or more years of service credit as a sworn police officer, 
(c)  Benefit Group F. The member has attained age fifty (50) years and has twenty (20) or more years of credited service earned while employed by the city as a firefighter. 
(d)  Benefit Group P. The member has attained age fifty (50) years and has twenty (20) or more years of credited service, served while employed by the city as sworn police officer. 
( Ord. No. C-3-2013, § 1 , 6-24-13)

Sec. 2-351. - Defined contribution pension plan withdrawals. 
    Former employees are eligible to take withdrawals from their 401(a) Defined Contribution Pension Plan when they leave employment of the city for any reason.
