ARTICLE V. - TEMPORARY OUTDOOR SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-101. - Statement of necessity. 
    The City of Farmington Hills hereby determines that, as it is necessary to protect the health and safety of persons and property within the city, temporary outdoor sales events should be licensed and controlled. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-102. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Temporary outdoor sales event or event includes, but is not limited to, whether for profit or not, outdoor sales, sidewalk sales, outdoor grand openings, and similar type activities, that are in connection with and on the same property as a permanent retail business or other permanent principal use, and are temporary and of such a nature as to be acceptable to the general public with regard to morals, health, safety features, and the conduct of the event participants. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-103. - Prohibited events. 
    After investigation by the city, no event judged to be a nuisance, safety hazard or otherwise not conforming to public welfare or morals shall be permitted and no license shall be issued to such event, nor permits granted for operation in the city. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07; Ord. No. C-10-2012, § 3, 7-23-12 ) 
Sec. 22-104. - Operation; public conduct. 
    The operation of any temporary outdoor sales event must be orderly and in keeping with the nature of the event, and any approval of the event. The event, and all persons attending the event, must comply with all applicable laws and ordinances at all times. Persons attending such event shall not create a disturbance, and the licensee shall not operate the event in such a way as to permit or encourage the creation of disturbances or breaches of the peace. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-105. - Exception. 
    This article shall not apply to Halloween pumpkin or Christmas tree sales regulated and licensed under article III of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Secs. 22-106-22-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-111. - Required. 
    No person shall conduct or operate a temporary outdoor sales event without having first procured a license for the event. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-112. - Application; fee. 
(a)  Applications for such licenses shall be made to the city clerk, and shall include all of the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  All of the partners, if the applicant is a partnership; 
(3)  All of the officers and directors, if the applicant is a corporation; 
(4)  The present resident addresses of all such persons; 
(5)  The address or parcel identification number(s) at which the event is to be conducted; 
(6)  The exact nature of the event; 
(7)  The date(s) of the event and the hours during which the event will take place on each day; 
(8)  Information as to whether the applicant, or any of its officers, directors or partners if it is a company, has ever been convicted of a felony; 
(9)  Information as to whether the applicant owns or occupies the property at which the event is to be held, and, if the applicant does not own the property, the applicant shall also furnish written consent from the owner of the property and shall provide proof that written notice has been given within seven (7) days of the date of submission of the application to the city to all other tenants, if any, on the property of the proposed event and applicant's intent to submit its application for a license to the city; 
(10)  Plans showing the layout of the event area, which plans shall identify all existing structures and improvements on the property where the event is to occur, and shall identify the location and describe all event-related temporary structures, tents, stands, ingress and egress, parking, traffic circulation, signs, lighting, electrical equipment, sound equipment, mechanical equipment, portable toilets, and any other information related to the event that may be requested by the city in order to make an informed decision regarding the issuance of a license for the event; and 
(11)  Such other information as may be required on forms as designated by the city, which shall be completed prior to such application being considered. 
(b)  A nonrefundable license fee shall be paid at the time the application is approved. The amount of the fee shall be determined by the city council. 
(c)  The completed application shall be submitted at least forty-five (45) days in advance of the event. The city may, but is in no way obligated to, consider an application submitted late, if the city manager determines in his or her discretion that exceptional circumstances exist and there is sufficient time for reviews, inspection and decisions to be made under this Code. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-113. - Investigation. 
    The city clerk shall refer such applications to the city manager, who shall instruct the various city departments to make an investigation of and report with recommendations concerning all aspects of the proposed event. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-114. - Zoning compliance. 
    No license shall be issued for the operation of any temporary outdoor sales event at any location where such use is not permitted under chapter 34 of this Code, unless the activity qualifies as a general exception under article XXIV of chapter 34 or the applicant has first obtained approval by the zoning board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-115. - License approval; issuance. 
(a)  Following receipt of the departmental reports and investigations, the city manager, or his or her designee, may approve, approve with conditions, or deny license applications for temporary outdoor sales events. An applicant aggrieved by the decision of the city manager under this subsection shall have the right to file an appeal of the decision to the zoning board of appeals within twenty-one (21) days of the city manager's decision in the manner provided under chapter 34 of this Code. 
(b)  If an application for a license is approved, the city clerk will issue the appropriate license with a statement of any applicable conditions upon completion of all requirements under this article and payment of the required license fee. The amount of such fee shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-116. - Duration of license. 
    Such license shall be issued for a period to be established by the city. Licenses issued hereunder are not renewable. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-117. - Bond required. 
    It shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of any license under this article that the applicant post with the city a valid liability insurance certificate and a clean-up bond deposit in amounts to be determined by a resolution of the city council. The condition of such deposit shall be that the licensee shall obey all of the laws of the State of Michigan and the ordinances of the City of Farmington Hills in connection with the event, shall cease all event activities on or before the expiration of the license, and shall remove all goods, equipment, tents, paraphernalia and other personal property related to the event from the premises on or before the expiration of the license. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Sec. 22-118. - Permits. 
    In addition to the requirement for obtaining a license for the event, other required permits for events under this article shall include, but not be limited to, the following areas: 
(1)  Health facilities. A permit from the Oakland County Health Department, if required by law, shall be obtained for any and all sanitary, water and food service facilities. 
(2)  Electricity. A permit from the city is required for all temporary generator or electric supply sources. All electrical work shall be done by a licensed electrical contractor. 
(3)  Fire hazards. Certification by the fire department of flame spread rates of all canvass and/or other cloth enclosures is required. Also, all fire department inspections and approvals required under applicable fire codes shall be obtained. 
(4)  Inspections; certificate of use. Fees shall be charged and paid for all inspections of the premises by the City of Farmington Hills. If the event and all inspections have been approved, the building division will issue a temporary certificate of use for the time period designated. 
(Ord. No. C-6-2007, § 1, 8-27-07) 
Chapter 23 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Junkyards near highways, MCL 252.201 et seq., MSA 9.391(11) et seq.; licensing of pawnbrokers, MCL 445.471 et seq., 446.201 et seq., MSA 19.581 et seq., 19.740(1) et seq.; licensing of secondhand and junk dealers, MCL 445.401 et seq., 445.471 et seq., MSA 19.711 et seq., 19.740(1) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 23-1-23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUNK DEALERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Business licensing generally, Ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Junkyards near highways, MCL 252.201 et seq., MSA 9.391(11) et seq.; licensing of secondhand and junk dealers, MCL 445.401 et seq., 445.471 et seq., MSA 19.711 et seq., 19.740(1) et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-26. - Refuse on premises. 
    Each junk dealer shall, at least once each month, and at any other time required by the city manager, remove all refuse material not suitable for sale or replacements on automobiles from the premises, and shall dispose of the same in such manner as may be directed by the manager. 
(Code 1981, § 51.260) 
Cross reference- Garbage and rubbish generally, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 23-27. - Hours. 
    No junk dealer shall conduct or operate any business licensed under this article between the hours of 7:00 p.m. on Saturday of each week, and the hour of 7:00 a.m. on the following Monday, or between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any secular day. 
(Code 1981, § 51.280) 
Sec. 23-28. - Records. 
    Each junk dealer shall keep a permanent written record, in such form as shall be prescribed by the police chief, of the model, serial number, engine number, year and make of each automobile purchased, received, sold, wrecked or dismantled, together with the license number on each and year issued, when available. Such record shall contain the name and address of each person from whom any such automobile was purchased, and the full name and address of each person to whom any such automobile was sold. Such records shall be open for inspection by any police officer during regular business hours. 
(Code 1981, § 51.290) 
Secs. 23-29-23-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 23-46. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in or carry on the business of dealing in junk, or maintain, operate or manage a junkyard or any place for the dismantling, wrecking or disposing of the junk and/or refuse material of automobiles, without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1981, § 51.210) 
Sec. 23-47. - Application; fee. 
    Any person desiring to secure a license under the provisions of this division shall file an application with the city clerk, upon forms furnished by the clerk, accompanied by a fee as specified in section 8-23, which fee shall be refunded if the license is not granted. Each application shall provide the following information: 
(1)  If an individual, the full name and address of the applicant, together with his or her name at birth; 
(2)  If an association, the nature of the association and the full name and address of each associate as required by paragraph (1) above; 
(3)  If a corporation, the full name and official address thereof with the date and state in which incorporated, and full name and address of the resident agent; 
(4)  The type of business proposed to be carried on; 
(5)  An accurate description of the premises proposed to be used in business together with a complete statement of ownership of such premises; 
(6)  A statement of any buildings to be constructed on the property, and any improvements to be made thereto; 
(7)  A statement as to use made of property fronting on a public highway on each side of the proposed location for a distance of one-half mile in each direction; 
(8)  The distance in each direction from the proposed location to the nearest intersecting public street or highway; 
(9)  An accurate description of the character of property and its use for a distance of one thousand (1,000) feet in each direction from the boundary lines of the property proposed to be used in the business; 
(10)  A statement as to whether or not the contemplated operation will involve the use of force or pounding, what machinery is to be used and whether or not any objectionable noise will be created; 
(11)  A statement as to whether or not any combustible or inflammable material will be used in the operation or stored on the premises and, if so, steps to be taken to avoid fires; 
(12)  Whether or not the operation of the business will be under the immediate personal supervision of the applicant; 
(13)  The names and address of persons to be employed in the operation; 
(14)  If applicant is an individual or an association, a statement of whether or not such applicant or any associate has ever been convicted of any crime or misdemeanor and, if so, the name of offense, date and place of conviction; 
(15)  Place of residence of the applicant for six-month period preceding date of application. 
(Code 1981, § 51.220) 
Sec. 23-48. - Review by council. 
    Upon receipt of any application under this division, the council shall, at its next regular meeting, or at any adjournment thereof, consider the application. The applicant shall have a right to appear before the council to furnish such additional information as may be required to enable the council to determine whether or not the application should be granted. The council may continue the consideration of the application from time to time for the purpose of securing additional information or to afford the public an opportunity to be present at the consideration thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 51.230) 
Sec. 23-49. - Certification by police chief, building inspector. 
    No junk dealer's license shall be issued except upon certification by the police chief and the building inspector. 
(Code 1981, § 51.210) 
Sec. 23-50. - Location of business. 
(a)  No license shall be granted under the provisions of this division when any part of the premises proposed to be used for any of the purposes hereinbefore set forth lies, within five hundred (500) feet in a direct line from the nearest point of any property used for church, synagogue, school, public library, hospital, sanitarium or private residence, except a residence owned by the licensee upon the premises described in the application. 
(b)  No license shall be granted under the provisions of this division when any part of the premises proposed to be used lies within three hundred (300) feet of an intersecting public street or highway. No license shall be granted hereunder unless at least fifty (50) percent of the property fronting on the public highway on each side of the proposed location, for a distance of one-half mile in each direction, is being used for business purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 51.240) 
Sec. 23-51. - Fence required. 
    The premises described in the application under this division shall, within a period of thirty (30) days after the granting of a license hereunder, be fully enclosed with a tight board fence, at least eight (8) feet in height and completely painted with white paint. Such fence shall be at all times kept in proper repair and properly painted by the licensee. 
(Code 1981, § 51.250) 
Sec. 23-52. - Changes in business; approval required. 
    No alteration in size, dimensions or buildings, or change in location of the premises described in the application under this division, shall be made at any time without the approval of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 51.270) 
Chapter 24 - SOIL PRESERVATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; flood damage prevention, Ch. 13; natural resources, Ch. 16.5; planning, Ch. 21; subdivision of land, Ch. 27; vegetation, Ch. 31; zoning, Ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Soil conservation districts law, MCL 282.1 et seq., MSA 13.1781 et seq.; soil erosion and sedimentation control act, MCL 282.101 et seq., MSA 13.1820(1) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 24-1-24-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOT GRADING AND DRAINAGE 

Sec. 24-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building contractor means the person holding a general contract for the construction of a building or structure. If no such person is employed by an owner, then in such cases the owner of the property affected shall be the building contractor. 
    Landscape contractor means a person, whether a licensed landscape contractor or not, who performs any grading, earth filling, earth removal, planting or landscape construction or maintenance work for hire. 
    Owner means, individually and collectively, the fee title holder, a land contract vendee, a lessee, a tenant of the property and the persons entitled to possession of property. 
(Code 1981, § 20.310) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 24-27. - Grading generally. 
(a)  Any home, building or structure erected in the city shall have the land surrounding the structure so graded as to readily carry all rain or surface waters away from such structure to a point where it will not infiltrate around the basement wall or foundation footings. 
(b)  The established grade on all types of homes in the city shall be not more than twenty (20) inches above or below the sidewalk or crown of the road. Special cases, where natural topography has an adverse effect upon drainage and where this provision would serve no good purpose, must have special approval from the department of public services; such approval shall be conditioned upon a determination by the department of public services that the proposed grade will not be injurious to the adjacent properties. 
(Code 1981, § 20.320) 
Sec. 24-28. - Residential driveway grading. 
    Any driveway which serves as a means of vehicular access to a residence shall have an established slope not to exceed seven (7) percent grade throughout its length and breadth; provided, however, that the slope may be increased to a grade not to exceed twelve (12) percent in those instances where the property owner files with the department of public services a signed statement acknowledging that the slope requested exceeds required and recommended standards. In special cases, where natural topography or other unusual conditions of the land make adherence to this requirement impractical, special approval of slopes in excess of twelve (12) percent grade may be granted by the department of public services under such reasonable conditions as may be determined to ensure no adverse consequences to adjacent property or to the public safety. 
(Code 1981, § 20.325) 
Sec. 24-29. - Responsibility for maintaining grade. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the building contractor to erect any home, building or structure in such a manner as to permit it to be graded in accordance with the requirements of section 24-27, and to construct and maintain such a grade until title to the property passes to another or until an occupancy permit is issued, whichever last occurs. Thereafter, the owner of such property shall maintain such grade or slope. 
(b)  The building contractor shall also be responsible for the structure thereon so that it is in accordance with the drainage plan that may have been established in any approved subdivision plat. If there is no drainage plan in the plat or none which will accomplish the requirement of this section, then the grading must be accomplished and maintained in such a manner so as not to obstruct, impede, accelerate, channel or concentrate the flow of rainwaters or surface waters onto or from the lands of another so as to cause damage thereto or create a nuisance thereon. The building contractor shall maintain such grade until title to the property passes to another or until an occupancy permit is issued, whichever last occurs. Thereafter, the owner of such property shall maintain such grade or slope. 
(c)  The building contractor shall be responsible for the adjustment of public utility structures, including, but not limited to, sanitary sewer and storm sewer manholes, watermain gate valves, fire hydrants, storm drain catch basins and cleanouts, located on the property upon which the structure is to be built or within the confines of his site grading or access in accordance with standards and specifications established by the department of public services. At the discretion of the director of public services, a separate inspection may be required to ensure conformance to the standards and specifications. Fees charged for the inspection shall be established by resolution of the city council and paid by the building contractor. 
(Code 1981, § 20.330; Ord. No. C-6-90, § 1, 2-19-90) 
Sec. 24-30. - Landscape contractor's duties. 
    No landscape contractor shall grade the surface of any property, fill it with earth, remove earth, do any planting or landscape construction or maintenance work which shall create a condition that prevents rainwaters or surface waters from draining in the manner required by sections 24-27 and 24-29. 
(Code 1981, § 20.340) 
Sec. 24-31. - Residential improvement permit. 
    Prior to the issuance of a building permit the owner and/or contractor of any single-family home, building or structure shall file a grading plan with the city's engineering division. Simultaneously with the filing of the grading plan the owner and/or contractor shall pay a review and/or inspection fee in an amount as established by resolution of the council. The engineering division will review the plan to determine if such plan conforms to all city requirements. Upon approval of such plan the city will issue a residential improvement permit. All construction shall conform to the approved grading plan. 
(Code 1981, § 20.350) 
Secs. 24-32-24-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, adopted Sept. 14, 2009 , amended Art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 24-51-24-58, pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
State Law reference- Soil erosion and sedimentation control act, MCL 282.101 et seq., MSA 13.1820(1) et seq. 

Sec. 24-51. - Enforcing agency. 
    The public services department shall be the municipal enforcing agency responsible for administering and enforcing Part 91, Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451 as amended ("Part 91") within the municipal limits of the city. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-52. - Rules adopted. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference the latest rules (the "rules") promulgated by the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality pursuant to Part 91. Such rules shall be available for public distribution, at a reasonable charge, with not less than ten (10) copies to be available for public inspection at the office of the city clerk and/or the department of public services. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-53. - Submission of plans. 
    Before undertaking any earth change activity in the city, unless exempted in Part 91 or the rules, disturbing one (1) or more acres of land, or within five hundred (500) feet of the water's edge of a lake or stream, the landowner shall secure a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit. Prior to receiving the permit, the landowner shall submit a soil erosion and sedimentation control application and plan to the city in accordance with the rules adopted in this article. A stream includes any stream as defined in the rules and/or storm sewer discharging into the stream. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-54. - Review of plans; fee schedule. 
    Upon payment of the necessary fees to the city in accordance with a fee schedule to be determined by the council and amended from time to time by simple resolution, the plans submitted under this article shall be reviewed and approved and a permit shall issue, provided the plans meet the standards and specifications pursuant to Rule 1710 of the rules to prevent soil erosion and off-site sedimentation. Copies of any such resolution of the council determining a fee schedule shall be placed on file at the public services department office. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-55. - Application and permit forms. 
    Application and permit forms to be used in accordance with sections 24-53 and 24-54 shall be the state-prescribed application and permit forms, as expanded from time to time as may be deemed necessary by the director of public services. Copies of the current application and permit forms in use shall be placed on file at the public services department office. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-56. - Site inspection. 
    The director of public services or his/her designee shall inspect earth change sites to ensure compliance with the requirements of Part 91 and this article. Site shall be inspected at the frequency necessary to ensure compliance with Part 91 and this article, but will always be inspected at a minimum at the beginning of construction, during construction, and at the end of the project. The director of public services or his/her designee may utilize all compliance and enforcement actions authorized in Part 91 and the rules to bring sites into compliance with Part 91 and this article. In advance of the issuance of a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit, the landowner shall pay into escrow with the city, an amount determined by the director of the public services department, or his/her designee, to be sufficient to cover the costs of the inspections for the project under this section, which amount shall be determined based upon the size of the project, expected construction and restoration period, anticipated number of inspections, and the inspection hourly fee schedule established by the council and amended from time to time by simple resolution. If it is at any time determined by the director of the public services department, or his/her designee, that the escrowed amount will be insufficient to cover the city's costs of inspection, the director of the public services department, or his/her designee, shall thereafter, from time to time, as required, request and the owner shall pay, additional amounts into escrow as reasonably estimated by the director of the public services department, or his/her designee, to be necessary to proceed with and complete the inspections in accordance with this section and Part 91, and all rules, regulations and policies established thereunder. Failure to pay such additional amounts shall constitute a violation of this Code and the soil erosion and sedimentation control permit issued by the city. The costs incurred by the city for any inspections that are necessary due to other violations requiring the city to construct, implement and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation controls on the property and for which the escrow is insufficient to cover, due to a failure to remit payment pursuant to this section, shall constitute a lien against the property for which the permit was issued, which lien shall have the force, effect and priority as provided under Section 9120 of Part 91. To the extent such an escrow exceeds the actual cost and expense of the inspections for the project, as ultimately determined, the excess shall be returned to the person or entity that posted the escrow. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-57. - Performance bond. 
    At the time that an application for a permit and plans are filed with the city in accordance with section 24-53, the applicant shall also deposit with the city a permit performance bond, being a cash deposit or irrevocable letter of credit in an amount to be specified by resolution of the council to guarantee completion of soil erosion and sedimentation control measures as approved in the soil erosion and sedimentation control plans. The permit performance bond shall be returned to the applicant after final inspection and approval under section 24-56. The permit performance bond shall be forfeited where work is commenced under any permit issued in accordance with section 24-54 and the conditions of the permit and soil erosion and sedimentation control plan are not completed prior to the expiration of the permit. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Sec. 24-58. - Appeals. 
    Any person feeling aggrieved by the actions of the public service department under this article may appeal to the board of appeals established under article IV of this chapter, which shall grant a hearing on the appeal within thirty (30) days thereof. Any decision of the board of appeals cannot be contrary to the requirements of Part 91 and the rules. The decision of the board of appeals shall be final. 
( Ord. No. C-8-2009, § 1, 9-14-09 ) 
Secs. 24-59-24-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LANDFILLS 

Sec. 24-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Engineering division means the city department of public services, engineering division of the public works division. 
    Soil means topsoil, subsoil, sand, gravel, rock, stone and other heavy aggregate, earth or any other material proposed to be dumped on land. 
(Code 1981, § 64.010) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 24-77. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the residents of the city and preserve the natural resources and to prevent the creation of nuisances and hazards to the public welfare, health, safety and well-being. 
(Code 1981, § 64.020) 
Sec. 24-78. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump any soil or other material upon or into any land in the city without a permit therefor. No permit will be required where the moving, grading or leveling of the aforesaid material is carried on for the immediate use or development of the land upon which these substances are found or pursuant to a residential improvement permit or site plan approved by the engineering division. Where soil or other substances are removed from the site or development where found to another site or development, a permit as mentioned above will be required. 
(Code 1981, § 64.030) 
Sec. 24-79. - Fills of one thousand cubic yards or less. 
    Where the entire volume of a fill required or contemplated does not exceed one thousand (1,000) cubic yards, the application for a permit may be filed with the engineering division. The engineering division may request such information from the applicant as is necessary to determine that the fill requested will meet the requirements of this article. The engineering division shall issue the permit if it is satisfied that: 
(1)  The fill will not impede drainage. 
(2)  The fill will not unreasonably alter the topographical drainage with regard to adjoining properties. 
(3)  The fill will not be in violation of any provision of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 64.040) 
Sec. 24-80. - Fills over one thousand cubic yards. 
(a)  The application for any permit where the entire volume of the fill required or contemplated exceeds one thousand (1,000) cubic yards shall be filed with the city clerk in quadruplicate, the original of which shall be sworn to before some person lawfully authorized to administer oaths, and shall be set for the following information and shall be accompanied by the following data: 
(1)  A full identification of the applicant and all persons to be directly or indirectly interested in the permit if granted; 
(2)  The residence and business address of the applicant, including all members of any firm or partnership or all officers and directors of any corporation applying; 
(3)  A complete description and location of the property on which the work is proposed to be done by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor; 
(4)  A topographic map of the property on which the proposed work is to be done including an area having a radius of three hundred (300) feet from the exterior boundary of the proposed site; 
(5)  The exact nature of the proposed soil to be dumped and an estimate of the approximate number of cubic yards to be dumped; this computation to be made by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor; 
(6)  A statement of the manner in which it is proposed to dump the soil or other materials, including the slope of the sides and ground levels, and the kind of equipment proposed to be employed in making such fill; 
(7)  The proposed route which the applicant proposed to use over the public streets and over private property in transporting such materials; 
(8)  The past experience of the applicant in the matter to which the permit appertains and the name, address and past experience in such matter of the person to be in charge of the proposed operations; 
(9)  The location of the place and the name and address of all persons and firms from whom the bulk of soil and any materials to be dumped are to be obtained; 
(10)  Whether or not any permit of the applicant has been revoked and if so, the circumstances of such revocation; 
(11)  The time within which such dumping is to be commenced after the granting of the permit and the time when it is to be completed; 
(12)  Such further information as the city may require. 
(b)  Immediately upon the filing of an application for a permit, one (1) copy thereof shall be delivered to the city engineer. The engineer shall make an investigation of the facts set forth in the application and shall make a written report of his or her investigation, together with his or her recommendations, to the city clerk who shall set a hearing by the council. Such hearing may be continued from time to time as the circumstances may require. 
(c)  Notice of hearing of an application shall be given by the city clerk by posting a notice thereof in a local paper designated for that purpose and by mailing a copy thereof addressed to the applicant and to the owners of all property, as appears on the last city assessment roll within five hundred (500) feet radius of the exterior boundaries of the proposed site, at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. Such notice shall contain a statement of the time and place of the hearing of the application, the name of the applicant, a general description of the premises where the applicant proposed to do the work, and a general statement of the size and nature of the proposed dumping area. 
(d)  The council shall require, as condition to the granting of any permit applied for, that the applicant deposit a surety bond, in an amount to be fixed by the council insuring to the benefit of the city and the general public guaranteeing that the applicant will faithfully perform all of the conditions and requirements under which the permit is issued. The council shall also require, as a condition to the granting of any such permit, that the applicant deposit a certificate of a responsible indemnity company, in an amount reasonably relevant to the proposed work to be done, insuring the city and the public against any loss or damage to persons or property arising directly or indirectly from the operations of the applicant, or any person acting on his or her behalf in carrying on any work connected directly or indirectly with the issuance of the permit. Such bond shall be held by the city until all of the requirements of this article have been fulfilled, but in any event, such bond shall not be cancelled until one (1) year after the filling is completed. 
(e)  The council in granting or denying any application shall take into consideration the zoning of the proposed site, character of the application as respects morality, honesty and integrity, financial responsibility, and all pertinent things concerning the proposed application which may concern the health, safety, well-being and general welfare of the public, the preservation of natural resources and the preventing of nuisances and hazards, and shall exercise a reasonable and sound discretion in the premises. Any permit for which application is made shall be denied if it appears from the investigation thereof that the project would result in a dangerous topographic condition, or result in seepage or slides or create an attractive nuisance dangerous to public safety, or that it otherwise would in any manner endanger the public health, and prevent the preservation of natural resources, or be detrimental to the general public welfare. 
(f)  Upon approval by the council the applicant will obtain from the engineering division a written authorization to proceed with fill. Noted on this form shall be: 
(1)  The starting date; 
(2)  The completion date; 
(3)  The owner and the owner's address; 
(4)  The owner's engineer and the engineer's address; 
(5)  The date of council approval. 
This authorization shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the site and shall remain there until the completion. No fill will be allowed without this authorization. 
(Code 1981, § 64.050) 
Sec. 24-81. - Fees. 
    At the time of application under this article the applicant shall pay an application fee and at the time of the issuance of the permit, if the application for the landfill is granted, the applicant shall pay a permit fee, such fee to be established by resolution of the council. The fees and/or costs heretofore mentioned in this article shall have no effect on any additional fees and/or costs as required by other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 64.060) 
Sec. 24-82. - Conditions for permit issuance. 
    Any person to whom any permit is issued to make a landfill shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Within six (6) months following dumping, the parcel of land must be graded and a turf established in such manner as to prevent the collection of water, to provide proper drainage and to leave the ground surface fit for the land uses permitted in the district. 
(2)  No soil or other material shall be dumped on the spillways or floodplains of any natural or artificial streams or watercourses, or any area between the upper and lower banks of such streams or watercourses, except on the approval of the council after a public hearing and on a satisfactory showing that such dumping will not result in damage to other property within the city limits and will not be detrimental to the public health, safety, preservation of natural resources or welfare. 
(3)  Waste and rubbish dumping shall be prohibited unless authorized by license by the state. 
(Code 1981, § 64.070) 
Sec. 24-83. - Termination, revocation, suspension of permit. 
(a)  At any time that the number of cubic yards dumped amounts to the number of cubic yards set forth in the estimate filed with the original application under this article, the permit granted shall terminate and no further materials may be dumped on the site until a new application has been filed and a permit granted in the same manner as the original application and permit. Any permit granted hereunder may be revoked or suspended for failure to comply with any of the provisions of this article. Revocation of such permit shall be made only upon a hearing granted to holder of the permit held before the council after five (5) days' notice to such permit holder stating the grounds of complaint against permittee stating the time and place where such hearing will be held. If in the opinion of the city manager the public health, safety or welfare requires it, the city manager may suspend any permit granted hereunder pending the hearing for the revoking of such permit by the council. Such revocation or suspension of any permit shall be in addition to any other penalties more specifically provided in chapter 1 of this Code. 
(b)  If any work for which a permit has been granted is not commenced within three (3) months from the date of granting of the permit or if work is started on excavations pursuant thereto and the work is abandoned for a period of three (3) months, the permit shall automatically expire by limitation and cease to be valid for any purpose. 
(Code 1981, § 64.080) 
Secs. 24-84-24-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MINING AND EXCAVATING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-106. - Definition. 
    The word "excavation" as used in this article shall include holes, pits, diggings or other cavities in the surface of the earth. 
(Code 1981, § 64.280) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 24-107. - Conditions of operation. 
    All premises licensed under this article shall be equipped with the following safety precautions as condition precedent to the issuance of such license: 
(1)  A six-foot chain-link-type fence or other fence of equal quality, approved by the city manager, shall be constructed around the entire area from which material is or has been taken, it being the intent of this provision to require fencing of all excavations, whether or not such excavations are presently being worked. Such fence shall be equipped with proper gates, which shall be kept securely locked at all times when operations are not being carried on. When such gates are not locked they shall be guarded by a person of full age and discretion. 
(2)  If such premises lie with one-half mile of any subdivided property on which ten (10) or more homes have been constructed, a watchperson shall be on duty on such premises at all times. 
(3)  No water shall be allowed to stand in any such pit or excavation unless such is fed by springs or other natural means except rainwater or surface water. 
(4)  No children shall be allowed within such fence at any time, unless under the direct control and supervision of an adult. 
(5)  No swimming shall be permitted in any such pit or excavation at any time. 
(6)  All trucks used in hauling gravel, sand or other minerals from the property shall proceed by the shortest route over section line roads to and from the nearest paved highway and shall not travel on gravel or unpaved roads except as necessary to reach such highway; provided, however, that an alternate route may be approved by the city manager. 
(7)  If any explosives of any kind are used in mining sand, gravel or other mineral, such use shall be under the direct supervision of persons licensed and fully experienced in such use, who shall notify the city manager of the intended use of explosives. Millisecond delay fuses shall be used exclusively. 
(8)  No excavating shall be done so close to any adjoining property line as to endanger the lateral support for such adjoining property. 
(9)  All machinery used in such operations shall be maintained in proper condition, mechanically and otherwise. Machines powered with diesel or gasoline engines shall be muffled, as much as reasonably possible, to reduce noise and nuisance factors. 
(10)  No operations shall be carried on later than 6:00 p.m., nor shall any operations begin earlier than 7:00 a.m., nor shall any operations be carried on Sunday. 
(Code 1981, § 64.260) 
Sec. 24-108. - Inspection. 
    The city manager or the city manager's authorized agent, or any member of the public safety department, shall have the right to inspect the premises used under such license under this division at any reasonable time. 
(Code 1981, § 64.270) 
Secs. 24-109-24-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Business licensing generally, Ch. 8. 

Sec. 24-126. - Required. 
    No person shall operate, maintain or allow to exist upon property owned, leased, subleased or used by such person, any gravel pit, sand pit or other excavation, presently or previously used for the taking of any mineral from the ground, unless such operation or premises is duly licensed as required by this division. 
(Code 1981, § 64.200) 
Sec. 24-127. - License application. 
    Application for licenses under this division shall be made to the city clerk. The application shall contain the name and address of the owner of the property; the name and address of the person conducting the operations thereon; a detailed description and topographical map of the property involved, including an estimate of the gravel, sand or other mineral being removed which still remains on the property, signed by a registered professional engineer or land surveyor; and an express agreement to conform to the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 64.210) 
Sec. 24-128. - Zoning compliance. 
    No license to operate any gravel pit, sand pit or other excavation shall be granted if the operation of such pit or excavation would be a violation of the zoning ordinance, it being specifically provided hereby that this article is subject to the provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1981, § 64.220) 
Sec. 24-129. - Consideration by council; bond; insurance. 
    All applications for licenses under this division shall be submitted to the council and shall be considered at a regular meeting thereof. A license, if granted by the council, shall become effective when the licensee shall deposit with the city clerk the following: 
(1)  A surety bond in a principal amount of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) for each acre or part thereof of the parcel of property for which the permit is sought, subject to a minimum bond of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), running to the city, issued by a corporate surety company licensed to do business in the state, and conditioned upon the licensee conforming to all of the requirements of this article. 
(2)  An original policy of liability insurance covering the licensee for the operations permitted by such license in limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for the injury to any one (1) person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person, per occurrence, for bodily injury, and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per occurrence for property damage. Such policy shall be endorsed to provide that it shall not be cancelled by the insurance company without ten (10) days' written notice to the city clerk. If such policy is cancelled, the license granted hereunder shall terminate automatically with such insurance. 
(Code 1981, § 64.230) 
Sec. 24-130. - Term. 
    Licenses under this division shall be issued for a term of one (1) year. 
(Code 1981, § 64.240) 
Sec. 24-131. - Transfer. 
    Licenses under this division are not transferable, but may be renewed in the same manner as originally granted. 
(Code 1981, § 64.240) 
Sec. 24-132. - Fees. 
    A license fee shall be paid at the time of application in accordance with council resolution and section 8-23. 
(Code 1981, § 64.250) 
Chapter 25 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26; taxation, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Power re special assessments, MCL 117.4a, 117.4b, 117.4d, 117.5; MSA 5.2074, 5.2075, 5.2077, 5.2084. 

Sec. 25-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cost, when referring to the cost of any improvement, shall include the cost of surveys, plans, rights-of-way, spreading of rolls, notices, advertising, financing and construction and all other costs incident to the making of such improvement, the special assessments therefor and the financing thereof. 
    Improvement means any public improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against one (1) or more lots or parcels of land to be especially benefited thereby, in proportion to the benefit to be derived therefrom. 
    Local roads means subdivision streets and similar streets of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting properties. This term shall not include expressways, major thoroughfares or secondary thoroughfares as defined in the thoroughfare plan of the city, either as existing or proposed. 
    Local water and sewer improvements means lateral sewers and distribution water mains intended primarily to serve properties abutting the improvement and specially benefiting therefrom. 
(Code 1981, § 5.110) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 25-2. - Council to make determination. 
    The council shall have the power to determine by resolution that the whole or any part of the cost or expense of any improvement shall be defrayed by special assessments upon the property especially benefited, in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived; provided, however, that the cost of local water and sewer improvements shall be borne one hundred (100) percent by the benefiting property and not more than twenty (20) percent of the cost of local road construction or improvement shall be borne by the city at large. 
(Code 1981, § 5.120) 
Sec. 25-3. - Advisory petitions. 
    The council, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desire any particular improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor, or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented; in either event, such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional. 
(Code 1981, § 5.130) 
Sec. 25-4. - Preparation of project plans; city manager's recommendations. 
    Before determining to make any improvement any part of the cost of which is to be defrayed by special assessment, the council shall require the city manager to have a registered professional engineer prepare plans and specifications therefor and an estimate of the cost thereof. The same shall be filed with the clerk, together with the city manager's recommendation as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which assessments may be paid and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Code 1981, § 5.140) 
Sec. 25-5. - Notice of hearing. 
    After filing of the project plans and specifications together with the city manager's recommendation, a public hearing shall be held before the council. The hearing shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice has been sent by the city clerk by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. Such notice shall specify the time and place of such hearing. The clerk shall also publish the notice of the hearing twice, the first publication to be not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(Code 1981, § 5.150) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1). 
Sec. 25-6. - Council to conduct hearing. 
    At the time and place specified in the notice for the public hearing, the council shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 5.160) 
Sec. 25-7. - Council resolution after hearing. 
    After the public hearing on a proposed project, the council may, by resolution, determine to make the improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefited in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. By such resolution the council shall approve the plans and specifications for the improvement; determine the estimated cost thereof; determine what proportion of such cost shall be paid by special assessment upon the property especially benefited and what part, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city; determine the number of installments in which assessments may be paid; designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied; and direct the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the council's determination. The rate of interest to be charged on such installments shall be one (1) percent above the average rate of interest borne by the bonds issued in anticipation of such special assessment. If bonds are not to be issued in anticipation of such special assessment, the rate of interest on such installments shall be determined by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 5.170) 
Sec. 25-8. - Preparation of special assessment roll. 
    The city assessor shall, upon the council resolution pursuant to the preceding section, prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the council, and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large. 
(Code 1981, § 5.180) 
Sec. 25-9. - Assessor's certificate; filing of roll. 
    When the city assessor has completed such assessment roll, the assessor shall attach thereto, or endorse thereon, his or her certificate to the effect that the roll has been made by him pursuant to a resolution of the council (giving date of adoption of same) and that in making the assessments therein he or she has, as near as may be, according to his or her best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution, and to the charter and the provisions of this chapter. Thereupon the assessor shall file the special assessment roll with the city clerk, who shall present the same to the council. 
(Code 1981, § 5.190) 
Sec. 25-10. - Council review of roll; notice. 
    Upon receipt of such special assessment roll the council shall order it filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination; shall fix the time and place when it will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice thereof has been sent by the city clerk by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. Such notice shall specify the time and place of such meeting. The city clerk shall also publish notice of the meeting twice, the first publication to be not less than ten (10) days prior to date of the meeting. 
(Code 1981, § 5.200) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq., MSA 5.3534(1) et seq. 
Sec. 25-11. - Objections to roll. 
    Any person deeming himself or herself aggrieved by the special assessment roll may file his or her objections thereto in writing with the city clerk prior to the close of the hearing, which written objections shall specify in what respect such person deems himself or herself aggrieved. 
(Code 1981, § 5.210) 
Sec. 25-12. - Council action on roll. 
    The council shall meet and review the special assessment roll at the time and place appointed, or at an adjourned date therefor, and shall consider any written objections thereto. The council may correct the roll as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land, or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the council's minutes. After such hearing and review the council may confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as it may have made, if any, or may refer it back to the city assessor for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. The city clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation upon each special assessment roll. 
(Code 1981, § 5.220) 
Sec. 25-13. - Confirmed rolls final. 
    Such special assessment roll shall, upon confirmation, be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1981, § 5.225) 
Sec. 25-14. - Assessment constitutes lien; payment by installments. 
(a)  All special assessments contained in any special assessment roll, including any part thereof deferred as to payment, shall, from the date of confirmation of such roll, constitute a lien upon the respective lots or parcels of land assessed and until paid shall be a charge against the respective owners of the several lots and parcels of land and a debt to the city from the persons to whom they are assessed. Such lien shall be of the same character and effect as the lien created by the charter for city taxes and shall include accrued interest and penalties. No judgment of decree, nor any act of the council vacating a special assessment, shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same, or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. 
(b)  All special assessments shall become due upon confirmation of the special assessment roll or in annual installments in number as the council may determine at the time of confirmation and, if in annual installments, the council shall determine the first installment to be due upon confirmation or on the following July first and subsequent installments shall be due on the July first of succeeding years. 
(Code 1981, § 5.230) 
State Law reference- Higher interest rates permitted when there are obligations in anticipation of special assessments, MCL 133.9, MSA 5.3188(12b). 
Sec. 25-15. - Collection of assessments generally. 
    The assessment roll shall be transmitted by the city clerk to the finance director/treasurer for collection immediately after its confirmation. The finance director/treasurer may mail statements of the several assessments to the respective owners, as indicated by the records of the city assessor, of the several lots and parcels of land assessed, stating the amount of the assessment and the manner in which it may be paid; provided, however, that failure to mail any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(Code 1981, § 5.240) 
Sec. 25-16. - Early payment. 
    The council may determine that the whole or any part of any special assessment may be paid during a determined period after the date of confirmation of the special assessment roll without interest or penalty. 
(Code 1981, § 5.245) 
Sec. 25-17. - Spreading installments. 
    The first installment of a special assessment shall be spread upon the next city tax roll in a column headed "Special Assessments" together with interest upon all unpaid installments from the date of the confirmation of the roll to the first day of July of the year in which such tax roll is made; provided, that any fraction of a month shall be considered as a full month. Thereafter one (1) installment shall be spread upon each annual tax roll, together with one (1) year's interest upon all unpaid installments: When any annual installment has been prepaid as hereinafter provided, then there shall be spread upon the tax roll for such year only the interest upon all unpaid installments. 
(Code 1981, § 5.250) 
Sec. 25-18. - Collection of installments. 
    After each installment of a special assessment has been placed on the tax rolls, the same shall be collected by the finance director/treasurer with the same rights and remedies, and the same penalties and interest, as provided in the charter for the collection of taxes. 
(Code 1981, § 5.260) 
Sec. 25-19. - Prepayment of installments. 
    After the expiration of the period provided for in section 25-16, any special assessment installment which has not been spread upon the tax rolls may be discharged by paying the face amount thereof plus the interest thereon to date of payment. Any person desiring to pay such installment in advance shall first secure the proper statement from the city assessor to permit the finance director/treasurer to compute the amount to be paid. The finance director/treasurer shall report to the assessor all advance payments on installments so that the assessor shall have such information before spreading installments on the next city tax roll. 
(Code 1981, § 5.270) 
Sec. 25-20. - Determination of actual cost of improvement. 
    Upon completion of the improvement and the payment of the cost thereof, the city manager shall certify to the council the total cost of the improvement, together with the amount of the original special assessment roll for such improvement. 
(Code 1981, § 5.280) 
Sec. 25-21. - Insufficient assessments. 
    Should the assessments in any special assessment roll, including the amount assessed to the city at large, prove insufficient for any reason to pay the cost of the improvement for which they were made, then the council shall make additional assessments against the city and the several lots and parcels of land, in the same ratio as the original assessments, to supply the deficiency; but the total amount assessed against any lot or parcel of land shall not exceed the value of the benefits received from the improvement. 
(Code 1981, § 5.290) 
Sec. 25-22. - Excessive assessments. 
    The excess by which any special assessment proves larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expenses incidental thereto may be placed in the general fund of the city if such excess is five (5) percent or less of the assessment, but should the assessment prove larger than necessary by more than five (5) percent, the entire excess shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the owners of the property assessed. No excess of less than five dollars ($5.00) shall be refunded in any event. Such refund shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments in the inverse order in which they are payable to the extent such installments then exist and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions of any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or part by such special assessment. 
(Code 1981, § 5.300) 
Sec. 25-23. - Reassessments. 
    Whenever any special assessment shall, in the opinion of the council, be invalid by reason of irregularity or informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the council shall, whether the improvement has been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment has been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for the original assessment. Whenever the assessment, or any part thereof, levied upon any premises has been so set aside, if the same has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. 
(Code 1981, § 5.310) 
Sec. 25-24. - Collection of delinquent assessments by suit. 
    In addition to any other remedies and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment, together with interest and penalties, may be collected in an action in assumpsit in the nature of the city against the person assessed, in any court having jurisdiction of the amount. If in any such action it shall appear that by reason of any irregularities or informalities the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant or upon the premises sought to be charged, the court may, nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city which is the proper charge against the defendant or the premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant or upon such premises. 
(Code 1981, § 5.320) 
Sec. 25-25. - Assessment confirmation to precede project. 
    No public improvement to be financed in whole or in part by special assessment shall be made before the confirmation of the special assessment roll for such improvement. 
(Code 1981, § 5.330) 
Sec. 25-26. - Single lot assessments. 
    When any expense has been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single premises, which expense is chargeable against the premises and the owner thereof under the provisions of this Code and is not of that class required to be prorated among the several lots and parcels of land in a special assessment district, an account of the labor, material and service for which such expense was incurred, with a description of the premises upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred, and the name of the owner, if known, shall be reported to the finance director/treasurer, who shall immediately charge and bill the owner, if known. The council shall, at such times as it may deem advisable direct the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll covering all such charges reported to it together with a penalty of ten (10) percent. Such roll shall be filed with the city clerk who shall advise the council of the filing of the same, and the council shall set a date for the hearing of objections to such assessment roll. The assessment roll shall be open to public inspection for a period of seven (7) days before the council shall meet to review the roll and hear complaints. The city clerk shall give notice in advance by publication of the opening of the roll to public inspection and of the meeting of the council to hear complaints and shall also give like notice to the owners of the property affected by first class mail at their addresses as shown on the current general assessment roll of the city, at least ten (10) days prior to the date of such hearing. Such special assessments and all interest and charges thereon shall, from the date of confirmation of the roll, be and remain a lien upon the property assessed, of the same character and effect as a lien created by general law for state and county taxes, until paid. Interest shall be paid on such assessments, when delinquent, from such date after confirmation as shall be fixed by the council, and such assessments, with penalties and interest, shall be added by the finance director/treasurer to the next general city tax roll or general county and school tax roll, as shall be convenient, and shall thereafter be collected and returned in the same manner as general city taxes. 
(Code 1981, § 5.340) 
Chapter 26 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Utility services, public improvements and contracts, Art. IX. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance authorizing public improvements saved from repeal, § 1-9(7); any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-9(11); buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; house moving, § 7-271 et seq.; community development, Ch. 9; parks and recreation, Ch. 19; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 20; planning, Ch. 21; special assessments, Ch. 25; subdivision of land, Ch. 27; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 30; vehicles for hire, Ch. 32; water and sewers, Ch. 33; zoning, Ch. 34; franchises, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Authority of city manager re additional regulations. 
    The city manager may make additional regulations pertaining to openings and excavations in the streets, curbcuts, street obstructions and house moving, which regulations shall be subject to the approval of the city council. No person shall fail to comply with any such regulations. 
(Code 1981, § 10.400) 
Sec. 26-2. - Removal of encroachments; recovery of expenses. 
    Encroachments and obstructions in the street or road right-of-way may be removed and excavations refilled and the expense of such removal or refilling charged to the abutting of landowner when made or permitted by or suffered to remain by such landowner otherwise than in accordance with the terms and conditions of this chapter. The procedure for collection of such expenses shall be as prescribed in section 25-26. 
(Code 1981, § 10.410) 
Sec. 26-3. - Temporary street closings. 
    The director of public services shall have the authority to temporarily close any street, or portion thereof, when the director deems such street to be unsafe or temporarily unsuitable for use for any reason. The director shall cause suitable barriers and signs to be erected on such street indicating that the same is closed to public travel. When any street or portion thereof has been closed to public travel, no person shall drive any vehicle upon or over such street except as may be necessary incidentally to any street repair or construction work being done in the area closed to public travel. No person shall move or interfere with any sign or barrier pursuant to this section without authority from the director. 
(Code 1981, § 10.420) 
Sec. 26-4. - Vacating streets. 
(a)  Whenever the council shall deem it advisable to vacate, discontinue or abolish any road, street or alley, or any part thereof, it shall so declare by resolution. In the same resolution the council shall appoint a time when it will meet and hear objections thereto. 
(b)  Notice of such meeting shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, not less than fifteen (15) days before the time appointed for such meeting. Notice shall also be given by first class mail to the owners of all property abutting such highway, street or alley, as shown upon the assessment rolls of the city. 
(c)  If after such hearing the council shall determine to vacate, discontinue or abolish such road, street or alley, it shall do so by resolution. The council may reserve an easement for public or private utility purposes within the right-of-way of any road, street or alley vacated, discontinued or abolished, and may by resolution extinguish any such easement whenever such easement ceases to be used for such utility purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 10.430) 
Secs. 26-5-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 

Sec. 26-26. - Definition. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of this term used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Street means all of the land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, alleys and boulevards in the city, and includes lawn extensions and sidewalks and the area reserved therefor where the same are not yet constructed. 
(Code 1981, § 10.010) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-27. - Damage, obstructions prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person shall make any excavation in or cause any damage to any street in the city, except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this article. No person shall place any article, thing or obstruction in any street, except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this article, but this provision shall not be deemed to prohibit the following: 
(1)  Such temporary obstructions as may be incidental to the expeditious movement of articles and things to and from abutting premises; 
(2)  The lawful parking of vehicles within the part of the street reserved for vehicular traffic; 
(3)  The planting of trees and shrubs, or placing any other installation therein when and as specifically authorized by any provision of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 10.020) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377 et seq., MSA 28.609 et seq. 
Sec. 26-28. - Permits, bonds, deposits. 
(a)  Where permits are authorized in this article, they shall be obtained upon application to the director of public services upon such forms as the director shall prescribe, and there shall be a charge provided by resolution of the council. Such permit shall be revocable by the director of public services for failure to comply with this article, rules and regulations adopted pursuant hereto, and the lawful orders of the director of public services or the director's duly authorized representative, and shall be valid only for the period of time endorsed thereon. Application for a permit under the provisions of this article shall be deemed an agreement by the applicant to promptly complete the work permitted, observe all pertinent laws and regulations of the city in connection therewith, repair all damage done to the street surface and installations on, over or within such street, including trees, and protect and save harmless the city from all damages or actions at law that may arise or may be brought on account of injury to persons or property resulting from the work done under the permit or in connection therewith. 
(b)  Where liability insurance policies are required to be filed in making application for a permit, they shall be in not less than the amounts as provided by resolution of the council. A duplicate executed copy or photostatic copy of the original of such insurance policy shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(c)  Where cash deposits are required with the application for any permit under this article, such deposit shall be in the amount as established by resolution of the council, and such deposit shall be used to defray all expenses to the city arising out of the granting of the permit and work done under the permit or in connection therewith. Six (6) months after the completion of the work done under the permit, any balance of such cash deposit unexpended shall be refunded. In any case where the deposit does not cover all costs and expenses of the city, the deficit shall be paid by the applicant. 
(Code 1981, § 10.030) 
Sec. 26-29. - Inspection. 
    Either full-or part-time inspection will be required by the director of public services pursuant to this article. Fees for these inspections shall be paid by the permittee in such amounts as established by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 10.035) 
Sec. 26-30. - Street openings generally; permit. 
    No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street without first obtaining a written permit from the director of public services. No permit shall be granted until the applicant shall post a cash deposit and file a liability insurance policy as required by section 26-28. 
(Code 1981, § 10.040) 
Sec. 26-31. - Emergency openings. 
    The director of public services may, if the public safety requires immediate action, grant permission to make a necessary street opening in an emergency, provided that a permit shall be obtained on the following business day and the provisions of this article shall be complied with. 
(Code 1981, § 10.050) 
Sec. 26-32. - Backfilling. 
    All trenches in a public street or other public place, except by special permission, shall be backfilled in accordance with regulations adopted pursuant to this article. Any settlement shall be corrected within eight (8) hours after notification to do so. 
(Code 1981, § 10.060) 
Sec. 26-33. - Placement of utility poles. 
    Utility poles may be placed in such streets as the director of public services shall prescribe and shall be located thereon in accordance with the directions of the director. Such poles shall be removed or relocated as the director shall from time to time direct. 
(Code 1981, § 10.070) 
Sec. 26-34. - Maintenance of installations in street. 
    Every owner of, and every person in control of, any estate hereafter maintaining a sidewalk vault, coal hole, manhole or any other excavation, or any post, pole, sign, awning, wire, conduit or other structure in, under, over or upon any street which is adjacent to or part of the estate shall do so only on condition that such maintenance shall be considered as an agreement on such person's part with the city to keep the same and the covers thereof, and any gas and electric boxes and tubes thereon, in good repair and condition at all times during such person's ownership or control thereof, and to indemnify and save harmless the city against all damages or actions at law that may arise or be brought by reason of such excavation or structure being under, over, in or upon the street, or being unfastened, out of repair or defective during such ownership or control. 
Sec. 26-35. - Moving of buildings, machinery, oversize vehicles. 
    No person shall move, transport or convey any building, machinery, truck or trailer more than eight (8) feet eight (8) inches wide or higher than thirteen (13) feet six (6) inches above the surface of the roadway or longer than fifty (50) feet into, across or along any street or other public place in the city without first obtaining a permit from the director of public services. The applicant shall file the written clearance from the light, telephone, gas and water utilities, stating that all connections have been properly cut off and, where necessary, all obstructions along the proposed route of moving will be removed without delaying moving operations. In addition, clearance shall be obtained from the department of public safety approving the proposed route through the city streets and the time of moving, together with an estimated cost to the department of public safety due to the moving operations. The applicant shall deposit with the city the total estimated cost to the department of public safety and the department of public services, plus a cash deposit as required by section 26-28, and shall file with the city a liability insurance policy in the amount as required by section 26-28. When the object to be moved is a building, article IX of chapter 7 shall be complied with. 
Cross reference- House moving generally, § 7-271 et seq. 
Secs. 26-36-26-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CURBCUTS 

Sec. 26-51. - Permit required. 
    No opening in or through any curb or any street shall be made without first obtaining a written permit from the department of public services, engineering division. Curbcuts and sidewalk driveway crossings to provide access to private property shall comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 10.110) 
Sec. 26-52. - Width of driveways. 
    The minimum width of a driveway approach at the sidewalk line shall be fourteen (14) feet and the maximum width of a single driveway approach at the sidewalk line shall be thirty (30) feet. 
(Code 1981, § 10.11(1)) 
Sec. 26-53. - Distance from crosswalks. 
    The minimum distance between any curbcut and a public crosswalk shall be five (5) feet. 
(Code 1981, § 10.110(2)) 
Sec. 26-54. - Distance between curbcuts.
