    The minimum distance between curbcuts, except those serving residential property, shall be determined on an individual basis by the director of public services. 
(Code 1981, § 10.110(3)) 
Sec. 26-55. - Size of sidewalk driveway crossings. 
    The maximum number of lineal feet of sidewalk driveway crossings permitted for any lot, parcel of land, business or enterprise shall be forty-five (45) percent of the total abutting street frontage up to and including two hundred (200) lineal feet of street frontage plus twenty (20) percent of the lineal feet of street frontage in excess of two hundred (200) feet. 
(Code 1981, § 10.110(4)) 
Sec. 26-56. - Adjustments to public improvements, installations. 
    The adjustments made necessary by curbcuts to utility poles, light standards, fire hydrants, catch basins, street or railway signs, signals or other public improvements or installations shall be accomplished without cost to the city. 
(Code 1981, § 10.110(5)) 
Secs. 26-57-26-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 26-76. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of certain terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Major roads: Roadways defined as city major streets, county primary roads, and state trunk lines in accordance with Act 51 of the Public Acts of 1951, as amended. 
    Owner: Any of the following: 
(1)  The person to whom real property is assessed on the city tax roll. 
(2)  The person in the process of developing property for residential use and constructing sidewalks as a part of common improvements to the development and who has not released the responsibility of maintenance of those improvements to an established homeowner or condominium association. 
(3)  The association of homeowners or condominium owners having the responsibility for the maintenance and repair of common areas of a residential development. 
    Sidewalk: The portion of the street right-of-way designed and improved for pedestrian and nonmotorized travel. 
(Code 1981, § 10.150; Ord. No. C-12-94, § 1, 7-18-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-77. - Adherence to specifications, permit required. 
    No person shall construct, rebuild or repair any sidewalk except in accordance with the line, grade, slope and specifications established by the city engineer nor without first obtaining a written permit from the department of public services, except that sidewalk repairs or [on] less than fifty (50) square feet of sidewalk may be made without a permit. The written permit shall be prominently displayed on the construction site. The fee for such permit shall be set by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 10.151) 
Sec. 26-78. - Line and grade stakes. 
    The department of public services shall approve line and grade stakes as may be necessary for proper control of work under this article. This shall not relieve the owner of the responsibility for making careful and accurate measurements in constructing the work to the line and grade approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1981, § 10.152) 
Sec. 26-79. - Construction, maintenance specifications. 
    Sidewalks shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the standards and specifications as established by the city engineer and approved by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 10.153) 
Sec. 26-80. - Permit revocation. 
    The director of public services may revoke any permit issued under the terms of this article for incompetency or failure to comply with the terms of this article or the rules, regulations, plans and specifications established by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 10.154) 
Sec. 26-81. - Obstructions. 
    The owner and/or occupant of every lot or premises adjoining any street, or the owner of such lot or premises, if same are not occupied, shall clear and keep clear all sidewalks adjoining such lot or premises from any obstructions including, but not limited to, structures, vehicles, materials, debris, vegetation or other similar items. 
(Code 1981, § 10.155) 
Sec. 26-82. - Maintenance. 
    No person shall permit any sidewalk which adjoins property owned by such person to fall into a state of disrepair or to be unsafe. 
(Code 1981, § 10.156) 
Sec. 26-83. - Sidewalks needing repair; notice to property owner; repair by city. 
(a)  Whenever the city manager determines that a sidewalk is unsafe for use, notice may be given to the owner of the lot or premises adjacent to and abutting upon such sidewalk of the city manager's determination. Such notice shall be given in accordance with subsection (c). Thereafter, it shall be the duty of the owner to place the sidewalk in a safe condition. Such notice shall specify a reasonable time, not less than ten (10) days, within which such work shall be completed with due diligence. 
(b)  If the owner of such lot or premises shall refuse or neglect to repair the sidewalk within the time limited therefor, or in a manner otherwise than in accordance with this article, the city manager shall have the sidewalk repaired. If the city manager determines that the condition of the sidewalk is such that immediate repair is necessary to protect the public, he may dispense with the notice and institute the repairs immediately. In any event, the cost of repairs under this section shall be charged against the premises which adjoins the sidewalk and shall be paid by the owner of the premises. If not paid, the cost of repairs shall be collected as provided in section 7.13 of the Charter. 
(c)  Notice regarding sidewalk repairs shall be served in the following manner: 
(1)  By delivering the notice to the owner personally or by leaving the same at the owner's residence, office or place of business with some person of suitable age and discretion; 
(2)  By mailing the notice by certified or registered mail to such owner at his or her last known address; or 
(3)  If the owner is unknown, by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the premises at least fifteen (15) days before the required work shall be completed. No person shall interfere with, obstruct, mutilate, conceal or tear down any official notice or placard posted by any city official, unless permission is given by such officer to remove the notice. 
(Code 1981, §§ 10.157, 10.158) 
Sec. 26-84. - Sidewalks located on major roads. 
    Section 26-83 shall not apply to sidewalks located along major roads. 
(Ord. No. C-12-94, § 2, 7-18-94) 
Sec. 26-85. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. C-12-94, adopted July 18, 1994 repealed § 26-85, which pertained to snow and ice removal, and was derived from Ord. No. C-64-85, § 1, adopted Dec. 9, 1985. 
Sec. 26-86. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any owner who believes the actions of the city manager pursuant to this article are improper may appeal the decision of the city manager to the council, provided such appeal is filed with the city clerk's office within ten (10) days of receipt or posting of a notice under this article. The appeal shall be in writing and shall state in clear and concise language the reasons for the appeal. 
(b)  The timely filing of an appeal shall stay all proceedings related thereto pending the outcome of the appeal. 
(c)  The city clerk shall immediately deliver a copy of the appeal to the city manager and shall place the appeal hearing on the agenda of the text available council meeting. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the appeal hearing, the council may affirm, modify or rescind the decision of the manager. The decision of the council shall be final. 
(Code 1981, § 10.159) 
Sec. 26-87. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any section of this article shall be responsible for a civil infraction and shall pay a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day a violation exists may be considered a separate violation and a fine so imposed. 
(Code 1981, § 10.160; Ord. No. C-59-85, § 1(10.190), 10-28-85) 
Secs. 26-88-26-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - USE OF SNOW REMOVAL EQUIPMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Removal or deposit of snow, ice, or slush which obstructs safety, vision, § 30-377. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-106. - Damaging public ways. 
    No person shall use any mechanically driven vehicle for the removal of snow from sidewalks, other pedestrian easements, streets or alleys in the city which will, by virtue of its use for such purpose, damage or tend to damage any sidewalk, improved easement, street or alley in the city. The use of mechanically driven vehicles for such purpose shall be lawful only where such mechanically driven vehicles do not cause such prohibited damage. 
(Code 1981, § 53.350) 
Secs. 26-107-26-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Business licensing generally, Ch. 8. 

Sec. 26-121. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of snow removal by the use of mechanically driven vehicles without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1981, § 53.360) 
Sec. 26-122. - Inspection of equipment. 
    No license shall be issued under this division until the director of public services shall determine whether any of the equipment which the applicant proposes to use would be detrimental to or tend to damage streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 53.360) 
Sec. 26-123. - Granted by director; fee; bond. 
    If the director of public services determines that the vehicle or equipment which the applicant for a license under this division proposes to use will not damage or tend to damage any street, alley or sidewalk the license may be granted upon payment of the fee and the filing of any bond or insurance which may be required in accordance with section 8-23. 
(Code 1981, § 53.360) 
Sec. 26-124. - Addition or substitution of equipment. 
    Any license issued under this division shall permit the use of only the equipment described in the application for the license. No licensee shall use other equipment without first obtaining approval therefor based upon an additional application fully describing such equipment which shall be submitted to the director of public services for the director's approval the same as in the case of a new application. An additional fee for the additional equipment shall be paid by the licensee but no additional annual fee for operation of the business shall be payable solely because of the addition or substitution of equipment. 
(Code 1981, § 53.360) 
Secs. 26-125-26-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 26-151. - Barricades, warning lights. 
    All openings, excavations and obstructions shall be properly and substantially barricaded and railed off, and at night shall be provided with prescribed warning lights. Warning lights perpendicular to the flow of traffic shall not be more than three (3) feet apart, and parallel to the flow of traffic not over fifteen (15) feet apart. 
(Code 1981, § 10.200) 
Sec. 26-152. - Sheeting and bracing. 
    All openings and excavations shall, where necessary, be properly and substantially sheeted and braced as a safeguard to workers and to prevent cave-ins or washouts which would tend to injure the thoroughfare or subsurface structure of the street. 
(Code 1981, § 10.210) 
Secs. 26-153-26-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - NATURAL BEAUTY ROADS 

Sec. 26-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City local road means dedicated public right-of-way other than an alley which affords the principal means of access to abutting residential property and is designated in accordance with Act No. 51 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1951 (MCL 247.651 et seq., MSA 9.1097(1) et seq.), as amended, as a local city road and is not designated in the city's master land use plan as a major thoroughfare. 
    City major road means dedicated public right-of-way other than an alley or local road, which affords a means of access through a city and is designated in accordance with Act No. 51 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1951 (MCL 247.651 et seq., MSA 9.1097(1) et seq.), as amended, as a "major" city road and is not designated in the city's master land use plan as a local roadway. 
    Native vegetation means an original or indigenous plant of this city including trees, shrubs, vines, wildflowers, aquatic plants or ground cover. 
    Natural means in a state provided by nature, without manmade changes, wild or uncultivated. 
(Code 1981, § 10.500; Ord. No. C-16-88, § 1, 5-9-88) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-177. - Petition and designation of natural beauty roads for city major roads. 
(a)  The council will be solely responsible for the preliminary designation of a natural beauty road. 
(b)  After the preliminary designation by the council proposing a city major road to be a natural beauty road, the department of public services shall report to council within six (6) months after such preliminary designation indicating the attributes of the particular roadway as it relates to the guidelines for designation to a city major road becoming a natural beauty road. 
(c)  Within thirty-five (35) days after the department of public services reports the necessary information, the council shall then hold a public hearing to consider designating the described portion of the road as a natural beauty road. The hearing shall be held at a suitable place within the city. At the hearing, a party or interested person shall be given the opportunity to present his or her support for or objections to the proposed designation. Notice of the hearing shall be given by the council by first class mail to all public utilities and all abutting property owners and by causing a notice thereof to be published at least once in each week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Also, such notice shall be provided by posting five (5) notices within the limits of the portion of the road to be designated in public and conspicuous places therein. The posting shall be done and at least one (1) publication in the newspaper shall be made at least not less than ten (10) days before the hearing. 
(d)  Within thirty (30) days after the hearing, if the council deems the designation desirable, it shall file with the city clerk and the county register of deeds, a true copy of its resolution designating the portion of the city major road as a natural beauty road. 
(Code 1981, § 10.505; Ord. No. C-16-88, § 2, 5-9-88) 
Sec. 26-178. - Revocation of natural beauty road designation for city major roads. 
    If council designates a road as a natural beauty road, this designation may be revoked by the council after it holds a public hearing in accordance with the procedure described in section 26-177 and makes a determination that the revocation of the natural beauty road designation is in the public interest. Within thirty (30) days after a hearing, if the council, by majority vote, determines the revocation necessary, it shall file with the city clerk and the county register of deeds a notice of its determination and publish the notice in a newspaper of general circulation once each week for two (2) successive weeks. After publication of the notice, the road previously designated shall revert to its former status. 
(Code 1981, § 10.506; Ord. No. C-16-88, § 3, 5-9-88) 
Sec. 26-179. - Petition and designation of natural beauty roads for city local roads. 
(a)  In order to initiate the possible designation of a natural beauty road, petitions requesting such designation containing the signatures of the property owners of record of fifty-one (51) percent or more of the lineal footage along the portion of road to be designated, and a petition signed by a minimum of twenty-five (25) or more freeholders of the city whose property does not abut the subject road shall be submitted to the city clerk. Such petitions shall conform to the standard form petition prepared and available at the office of the city clerk for designation of natural beauty roads. 
(b)  Within six (6) months after a petition is received, the department of public services shall determine the sufficiency of the petition and make a finding as to whether or not the portion of road proposed for designation meets the criteria adopted for the designation of natural beauty roads. The department shall report its findings to the council and notify the circulator of the petition as to the date the certification and report will be presented to the council. 
(c)  Within thirty-five (35) days after the department of public services certifies that a petition is sufficient and fulfills the criteria for designation, the council shall hold a public hearing to consider designating the described portion of road as a natural beauty road. The hearing shall be held at a suitable place within the city. At the hearing a party or interested person shall be given the opportunity to present support for or objections to the proposed designation. Notice of the hearing shall be given by the council by first class mail to all public utilities and all abutting property owners and by causing a notice thereof to be published at least once in each week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, and by posting five (5) notices within the limits of the portion of the road to be designated, in public and conspicuous places therein. The posting shall be done and at least one (1) publication in the newspaper shall be made not less than ten (10) days before the hearing. 
(d)  Within thirty (30) days after the hearing, if the council deems the designation desirable, it shall file with the city clerk and the county register of deeds a true copy of its resolution designating the portion of the city local road as a natural beauty road. 
(Code 1981, § 10.510; Ord. No. C-16-88, § 4, 5-9-88) 
Sec. 26-180. - Revocation of natural beauty road designation for city local road. 
(a)  If the council designates a road as a natural beauty road, the property owners of record of fifty-one (51) percent or more of the lineal footage along the natural beauty road may submit, at any time after the road is so designated, a petition to the council requesting that the natural beauty road designation be withdrawn. If the petition is valid, the designation as a natural beauty road shall be withdrawn. 
(b)  A designation of a natural beauty road may also be withdrawn or revoked by the council after the council receives a request from the city manager and holds a public hearing in accordance with the procedure described in section 26-179(c) and makes a determination that the revocation of the natural beauty road designation is in the public interest. Within thirty (30) days after a hearing, if the council by majority vote determines the revocation necessary, it shall file with the city clerk and the county register of deeds a notice of its determination and publish the notice in a newspaper of general circulation, once each week for two (2) successive weeks. After publication of the notice, the road previously designated shall revert to its former status. 
(Code 1981, § 10.520; Ord. No. C-16-88, § 5, 5-9-88) 
Sec. 26-181. - Uniform guidelines and procedures for major and local roads. 
(a)  The department of public services shall develop uniform guidelines and procedures which shall be adopted by the council for designating, maintaining and preserving natural beauty roads. No guidelines and procedures adopted under the authority of this article shall prohibit the application of accepted principles of sound forest management in a natural beauty road right-of-way. 
(b)  The department of public services may advise and consult with the council on the application of the guidelines and procedures. 
(c)  The council shall provide for a public hearing before an act is permitted which would result in substantial damage to native vegetation in the right-of-way. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall affect the right of a public utility to control vegetation in connection with public safety or the maintenance, repair or replacement of public utility facilities which were constructed in a road prior to its designation as a natural beauty road, or in connection with the construction, maintenance, repair or replacement of public utility facilities crossing a natural beauty road subject to the approval of the director of public services. 
(e)  When a local road is designated as a natural beauty road by council, a traffic-control order will be processed for twenty-five (25) miles per hour for the area designated as a natural beauty road. 
(f)  When a major road is designated as a natural beauty road by council, a traffic-control order will be adopted by council setting the speed limit at a speed taking into consideration not only the recommendations of the city's traffic engineer, but also the existing conditions, existing and proposed future development, the circumstances that give credibility to the designation to a natural beauty road and any other criteria affecting the proposed speed limit. 
(Code 1981, § 10.530; Ord. No. C-16-88, § 6, 5-9-88) 
Secs. 26-182-26-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DRAINAGE COURSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 26-201-26-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING OPERATIONS 

Sec. 26-216. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this division, the term "building contractor" shall mean any person holding a general contract for the construction of a building or structure. If no such person is employed by an owner, then in such cases the owner of the property affected shall be the building contractor. 
(Code 1981, § 11.010) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-217. - Applicability. 
    The operation of this division shall be restricted to the time extending from the date of issuance of a building permit to the date of issuance of an occupancy permit by the city. This division shall not be interpreted to refer to the depositing of any soil or debris in roadside ditches caused by the elements or by acts of nature. 
(Code 1981, § 11.020) 
Sec. 26-218. - Depositing materials in drainage way. 
(a)  Dirt, sand, gravel, clay or any other type of soil shall not be moved into or deposited in any roadside ditch, drain or gutter in the city after the time such ditch, drain or gutter is cut. 
(b)  Builders' materials of any sort or nature, or debris from any building operation, shall not be moved into or deposited in any roadside ditch, drain or gutter in the city after the time such ditch, drain or gutter is cut. 
(Code 1981, § 11.030) 
Sec. 26-219. - Depositing materials in right-of-way. 
    No building materials of any sort shall be unloaded or deposited or stored on any lands previously dedicated to the public use for right-of-way for a street. Buildings materials shall only be unloaded onto, deposited or stored on the private land adjoining such publicly dedicated right-of-way for street purposes to be served by such building materials. 
(Code 1981, § 11.040) 
Sec. 26-220. - Culvert installation. 
    After the cutting of a roadside drainage ditch, and before any building operations are continued or carried on upon private lands adjoining such roadside ditch, the building contractor shall provide and install a ditch culvert of corrugated steel, not less than twenty-two (22) feet in length, and of a diameter approved by the highway authority having jurisdiction, but not less than twelve (12) inches, and cover the same across the roadside drainage ditch with sufficient gravel to prevent damage to the corrugated steel culvert by vehicular traffic passing over the same. 
(Code 1981, § 11.050) 
Sec. 26-221. - Ditch installation. 
    The building contractor shall provide a roadside ditch across the entire frontage of the site, except where culverts are necessary for access or utility or tree interference. The requirements for this ditch shall be in accordance with the standards and specifications of the highway authority having jurisdiction over such road. 
(Code 1981, § 11.055) 
Sec. 26-222. - Contractor responsible for violations. 
    The building contractor shall be held prima facie responsible for the existence of any prohibited materials in roadside ditches, after the same are cut, within the area of the roadside ditch in front of the lot upon which the building contractor is conducting his or her operation. Such area shall be determined by the continuation of the side lot lines in their same direction until they will cross the roadside ditch, and the areas between such extended lines will be the roadside ditch area of such adjoining lot. 
(Code 1981, § 11.060) 
Sec. 26-223. - Notice to correct violation; stopwork order. 
    Upon the discovery by a city inspector of the existence of any prohibited materials in such roadside ditches, the inspector shall thereupon notify the building contractor of such violation by posting a notice on or in the house or structure being built upon the adjoining land, or by nailing such notice to a stake placed in the ground in a conspicuous position. At the same time such notice is posted, the city inspector shall, in a like manner, post a stopwork order on the building, which will prohibit any further building operations being carried on. If within twenty-four (24) hours after the posting of the first notice as provided above the building contractor shall have removed all prohibited materials from roadside ditches, and deposited the same on private lands adjoining, and shall have replaced the roadside ditch in the same condition as before, then the city inspector shall authorize the withdrawal of the notice of violation, and shall authorize the withdrawal of the stopwork order as provided above. If such prohibited material is not removed from the roadside ditch and deposited upon adjoining private lands, and the roadside ditch is not replaced to its previous condition within twenty-four (24) hours after the posting of such notice, the building contractor shall be guilty of a violation of this division. In such event, the stopwork order shall continue in effect and all building operations shall be prohibited until the violation is cured. 
(Code 1981, § 11.070) 
Sec. 26-224. - Security deposit. 
    Upon application for a building permit, the applicant shall deposit with his or her application a sum established by resolution of the council to guarantee that after completion of the building, the applicant shall remove or cause to be removed all debris, rubbish and trash from the building site and to establish ditches and culverts to properly drain the building area, and to reopen and reestablish any drainage that may have been interrupted by the building operation. All drains and culverts shall be established in accordance with the requirements and specifications of the highway authority having jurisdiction. The deposit shall be returned to the applicant upon demand after final inspection and approval by the city inspector. If, after approval by the city inspector, demand for the return of the deposit is not made by the applicant within one (1) year after the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, the sum shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 11.080) 
Secs. 26-225-26-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OBSTRUCTIONS 

Sec. 26-241. - Definition. 
    As used in this division, the word "drain" shall mean every ditch, stream, watercourse, swale, sewer, pipe or other conduit of any kind, whether natural or artificial, whether or not established by any public authority, over or through which surface waters normally pass within the city. 
(Code 1981, § 11.110) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-242. - Prohibited. 
    No person shall obstruct or cause to be obstructed any drain by any means whatsoever, so as to prevent or retard the free flow of surface waters thereon or therein. 
(Code 1981, § 11.120) 
Sec. 26-243. - Permitting obstruction. 
    No owner, lessee or other person in possession of any property over which a drain exists shall suffer or permit such drain to be obstructed by any means whatsoever so as to prevent or retard the free flow of surface waters thereon or therein, or suffer or permit such an existing obstruction to continue. 
(Code 1981, § 11.130) 
Sec. 26-244. - Increasing, diverting flow. 
    No person, other than a governmental agency authorized by law to manage drains or stormwater easements, shall divert, enclose, reconstruct or relocate any drain so as to cause such drain to discharge upon any property within the city, with increased force, in an increased amount or at a different location without the express written consent of all parties in interest in the property upon which the drain is to discharge. Such consent shall be in recordable form and shall be recorded in the office of the county register of deeds. 
(Code 1981, § 11.140; Ord. No. C-36-92, § 1, 9-21-92) 
Sec. 26-245. - Report of violation; determination re drainage area. 
    Any owner of property over which a drain is alleged to exist, or of property within the drainage area served by an alleged drain, who claims that such alleged drain has been or is being obstructed or diverted in violation of this division may petition, at his or her expense, the council to determine the existence of the drain, the location thereof and the properties drained thereby. Upon receipt of such a petition, the council may direct the engineering division to report to the council with respect to the location of the alleged drain, its history, the area drained thereby and any other pertinent facts concerning the drain. 
(Code 1981, § 11.150) 
Sec. 26-246. - Hearing; council determination. 
    Upon receipt of a petition submitted pursuant to section 26-245 and the report of the city engineer, the council shall hold a hearing thereon and shall give notice thereof by first class mail to the property owners affected in the manner provided in section 1-14 of this Code. Following such hearing the council may adopt a resolution defining the location of the drain and the property drained thereby. Such resolution shall be prima facie evidence thereof in any prosecution for violation of this division; provided, however, that the procedures described in section 26-245 and this section shall not be deemed to be conditions precedent to a prosecution for violation of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 11.160) 
Secs. 26-247-26-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ROADSIDE DRAINAGE DITCHES 

Sec. 26-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Driveway means every parking lot, private road, common driveway or similar feature, whether or not open for public use. 
    Gutter means the gutter area of a paved and curbed street. 
    Roadside ditch means every ditch, culvert, swale or other watercourse permitting the normal flow of water which drains off public streets and highways. 
(Code 1981, § 11.210) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-262. - Permit to construct driveway, install culvert across-Required. 
    No person shall cause the construction or connection of any driveway which crosses a roadside ditch nor install a culvert as may be required in this article, nor change the flow of water in any such roadside ditch, without first obtaining a permit from the department of public services. All connection or construction shall required the installation of a proper culvert as required by the department of public services. 
(Code 1981, § 11.220) 
Sec. 26-263. - Same-Application; fee. 
    Application for a permit to connect or construct a driveway across or through a roadside ditch, or to install a culvert as directed by authority of this article shall be made in writing to the department of public services on a form supplied by that department. Such application shall be accompanied by a permit fee in an amount set by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 11.230) 
Sec. 26-264. - Same-Performance bond. 
    No permit shall be issued under this division until a cash performance bond has been filed with the department of public services in an amount sufficient to insure performance of the work in conformity with the permit and rules, regulations and specifications of the department of public services; but in no event shall such bond be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). The amount of the cash bond shall be established by resolution of the council. Such bond shall be forfeited where the permitted construction, connection or installation is not in conformance with the rules, regulations and specifications of the department of public services, or when the permitted construction, connection or installation is not completed for final inspection and approval on or before the expiration date of the permit. 
(Code 1981, § 11.240) 
Sec. 26-265. - Inspection. 
(a)  Upon notification of completion of work permitted under this division to the department of public services, an inspector shall make an on-site inspection of the construction to determine whether the specification requirements have been met. 
(b)  If the construction is satisfactory, the permit holder will be refunded his or her bond upon application therefor to the department of public works. 
(c)  If the construction is not satisfactory, the permit holder shall be notified of all defects. Notification of deficiency may be given to any person of suitable age and discretion at that address, or by written message left in a conspicuous place at that address, if no such person is available, or by regular mail. 
(d)  The permit holder may correct such defects and request a second inspection upon payment of an additional inspection fee to the department of public services, prior to the expiration date of the permit. The amount of the fee shall be established by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 11.250) 
Sec. 26-266. - Existing driveways blocking. 
    When any owner of an existing driveway fails to maintain such driveway in accordance with the specifications and rules of the department of public services or of this Code by allowing the driveway, due to its particular construction or disrepair, partially or completely to block a roadside ditch, written notice of such defective condition shall be served upon the owner. Such notice shall require that the condition be corrected by a date certain, which date shall be not less than fifteen (15) days from the date of service of such notice. Within fifteen (15) days following service of such notice, the owner shall advise the city in writing of his or her intention to install the necessary culvert or perform the necessary repairs, and shall proceed with the required work in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1981, § 11.260) 
Sec. 26-267. - Service of notice of required repairs. 
    Notice of repairs required by authority of this division shall be given by the city by one (1) or more of the procedures provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1981, § 11.270) 
Sec. 26-268. - Plans, specifications, work subject to approval. 
    The size, quality, kind, grade and number of culverts to be installed and the kind, grade, quality and amount of all of the material to be installed, placed, used or deposited under the provisions of this division shall be subject to the prior approval of the department of public services, and all work and labor performed under the provisions hereof shall be performed under the control and supervision and subject to the approval of the department of public services. 
(Code 1981, § 11.280) 
Sec. 26-269. - Construction by city; recovery of costs. 
    Whenever the owner of real property notified pursuant to this division fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the division or any notices given by authority of this division within the time provided, the department of public services may cause the materials, work and labor set forth in such notice to be furnished by or on behalf of the city, and proceed to perform such work. Upon completion thereof, the cost of the work shall be charged against the premises and collected as prescribed in section 25-26 of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 11.290) 
Chapter 27 - SUBDIVISION OF LAND[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; community development, Ch. 9; flood damage prevention, Ch. 13; subdivision proposals for flood damage prevention, § 13-7; planning, Ch. 21; soil preservation, Ch. 24; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26; motorcycles restricted on subdivision streets, § 30-684; water and sewers, Ch. 33; zoning, Ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Subdivision Control Act, MCL 560.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Purposes. 
    The purposes of this chapter are to provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community; to secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivisions and public facilities; to achieve individual property lots of maximum utility and livability; to secure adequate provisions for water supply, drainage and sanitary sewerage, and other health requirements; to secure adequate provisions for recreational areas, school sites and other public facilities; and to provide logical procedures for the achievement of these purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 61.020; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 1, 1-13-97) 
Sec. 27-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. All terms as defined in the subdivision act shall control in this chapter unless indicated to the contrary in this section. 
    Block: Property abutting one side of a street and lying between the two (2) nearest intersecting streets, unsubdivided acreage, river or live stream; or between any of the foregoing and any other barrier to the continuity of development. 
    Common element: The portions of the condominium project other than the condominium unit. 
    Condominium Act: Act No. 59 of the Public Acts of 1978 (MCL 559.166), as amended. 
    Condominium subdivision plan: The drawings and information pursuant to section 66 of 1978 PA 59 (MCL 559.166), as amended. 
    Condominium unit: That portion of the condominium project designed and intended for separate ownership and use as described in the master deed. 
    Co-owner: A person, firm etc. who owns a condominium unit. Co-owner may include a land contract vendee if the condominium documents or the land contract so provide. 
    Easement: A grant by the owner of the use of a strip of land by the public, a corporation or persons, for specific uses and purposes, to be designated as a public or private easement depending on the nature of the use. 
    Engineer: The city engineer or consulting engineer for the city. 
    General common elements: The common elements other than the limited common elements. 
    Improvements: Grading, street surfacing, curb and gutter, sidewalks, crosswalks, water mains and lines, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, culverts, bridges, utilities and other additions to the natural state of land which increases its value, utility or habitability. 
    Limited common elements: A portion of the common elements reserved in the master deed for the exclusive use of less than all of the co-owners. 
    Lot: A parcel of land the dimensions of which are shown on a document or map prepared in conformance with the subdivision act or condominium act. For purposes of this chapter, a lot shall be equivalent to a condominium unit and those limited common elements surrounding a condominium unit devoted exclusively to the use of the co-owners of the unit. 
    Major street or thoroughfare plan: The part of the master plan which sets forth the location, alignment and dimensions of existing and proposed streets and thoroughfares. 
    Master plan: The comprehensive land use plan for the city, including graphic and written proposals indicating the general locations recommended for the streets, parks, schools, public buildings, zoning districts and all physical developments of the city, and includes any unit or part of such plan separately adopted, and any amendments to such plan for parts thereof duly adopted by the planning commission. 
    Plan: A map or chart of a subdivision of land prepared in conformance with either the Subdivision Act or the Condominium Act. 
(1)  Preliminary plan: A map showing the salient features of a proposed subdivision plat or condominium subdivision plan submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary consideration. For purposes of a subdivision plat, a preliminary plan is equivalent to a preliminary plat. 
(2)  Final plan: A map of all or part of a subdivision plat or condominium subdivision plan providing substantial conformance to the preliminary plan prepared in conformance with state law and this chapter and suitable for recording by the county register of deeds. For purposes of a subdivision plat, a final plan is equivalent to a final plat. 
    Planner: The city planner or consulting planner for the city. 
    Proprietor: A natural person, firm, associate, partnership, corporation or combination of any of them which may hold any ownership interest in land whether recorded or not. 
    Road commission: The board of county road commissioners. 
    Street: Any street, avenue, boulevard, road, lane, parkway, viaduct, alley or other way which is an existing state, county or municipal roadway; or a street or way shown in a plan heretofore approved pursuant to law or approved by official action; or a street or way on a plan duly filed and recorded in the office of the county register of deeds. A street includes the land between the street lines, whether improved or unimproved, and may comprise pavement, shoulders, gutters, sidewalks, parking areas; and lawns. 
(1)  Major thoroughfare: An arterial street of great continuity which is intended to carry intercounty or interregional traffic for both the immediate city area and region beyond, and may be designated in the city's thoroughfare plan as a major thoroughfare or freeway. 
(2)  Secondary thoroughfare: A thoroughfare designated to carry intercity traffic and designated in the city's thoroughfare plan as a secondary thoroughfare. 
(3)  Primary collector street: A street used primarily to carry traffic from local streets to major or secondary thoroughfares and designated in the city's thoroughfare plan as a primary collector. 
(4)  Minor street: A local street of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting residential properties. 
(5)  Marginal access street: A minor street paralleling and adjacent to a major or secondary thoroughfare which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
(6)  Boulevard street: A street developed to two (2) two-lane, one-way pavements separated by a median. 
(7)  Turnaround: A short boulevard street permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
(8)  Cul-de-sac street: A short minor street having one (1) end permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
(9)  Alley: A minor service street used primarily to provide secondary vehicular access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting upon a street. 
    Subdivision: A subdivision of land in conformance with either the Subdivision Act and this chapter, or the Condominium Act and this chapter. 
    Subdivision Act: The Land Division Act (formerly known as the Subdivision Control Act), being Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1967, as amended (MCL 560.101 et seq.). 
(Code 1981, § 61.050; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-3-2006, § 1, 3-20-06) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 27-3. - Interpretation. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion and preservation of public health, safety and general welfare of the city. This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any manner interfere with existing regulations or laws of the state, except that this chapter shall prevail in cases where this chapter imposes a greater restriction than is provided by existing statutes, laws or regulations. 
(Code 1981, § 61.050; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 1, 1-13-97) 
Sec. 27-4. - Fees. 
    The fees set forth by resolution of the council for the review of plats, plans, divisions and applications are adopted and established as the fees that shall be paid by the proprietor at the time of filing of the plat, plan, division or application (including revisions thereof) with the city or at the time inspection is requested. Such fees shall be in addition to any and all fees required by any statute of the state or any other provision of this Code. 
(Code 1981, §§ 61.660-61.690; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 1, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-3-2006, § 1, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 27-5. - Variance for hardship. 
    The council or planning commission may authorize a variance from this chapter when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance and provided the variance does not pertain to requirements of the zoning ordinance. In granting any variance, the council or commission shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required hereinbelow, the council or commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the council or commission finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of the applicant's land. 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner. 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
(Code 1981, § 61.700) 
Sec. 27-6. - Variance for complete community. 
    The council may authorize a variance from this chapter in case of a plan for a complete community where such development is permitted by the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1981, § 61.750) 
Secs. 27-7-27-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATTING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 27-36. - Generally. 
    The preparation of a subdivision for approval shall be carried out through two (2) phases: preliminary plan and final plan, all in accordance with the procedure as set out in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 61.110; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 2, 1-13-97) 
Sec. 27-37. - Initial investigation and pre-application meeting. 
(a)  Prior to the preparation of a preliminary plan it is suggested that the proprietor meet informally with the city officials concerned to investigate the procedures and standards of the city with reference to this chapter and with the proposals of the master plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. The proprietor should not submit a preliminary plan at this time. 
(b)  The proprietor should concern himself or herself with the following factors: 
(1)  The proprietor shall secure a copy of the zoning chapter, subdivision regulations, engineering specifications and other similar ordinance provisions or controls relative to the subdivision and improvement of land so as to become aware of the requirements of the city. 
(2)  The area for the proposed subdivision shall be properly zoned for the intended use. 
(3)  An investigation of adequacy of existing schools and the adequacy of public open spaces including parks and playgrounds to serve the proposed subdivision shall be made by the proprietor. 
(4)  The relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for widening of thoroughfares shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(5)  Standards for sewage disposal, water supply and drainage of the city shall be investigated by the proprietor. 
(c)  In addition to the initial investigation, the proprietor of a subdivision plat may request that a pre-application review meeting take place by submitting a written request to the chairperson of the county plat board and submitting copies of a concept plan for the preliminary plat to the city and to each officer or agency entitled to review the preliminary plat under the Subdivision Act. A pre-application review meeting shall take place not later than thirty (30) days after the written request and concept plan are received. The meeting shall be attended by the proprietor, representatives of each officer or agency required to attend under the Subdivision Act, and a representative of the city. The purpose of the meeting is to conduct an informal review of the proprietor's concept plan for the preliminary plat. This provision does not apply to the proprietor of a condominium subdivision plan. 
(Code 1981, § 61.120; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 2, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-3-2006, § 2, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 27-38. - Preliminary plan-Preparation; submittal; tentative approval. 
    The procedure for preparation and submittal of a preliminary plan of the land area to be subdivided for tentative approval shall be as follows: 
(1)  Filing: 
a.  Ten (10) copies of the preliminary plan of the proposed subdivision, together with written application in triplicate, shall be submitted to the city clerk. 
b.  The preliminary plan shall be prepared in accordance with state law and in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. It shall not be necessary that initial submission be prepared by and sealed by a surveyor, provided that properly sealed copies of the preliminary plan are filed with the city prior to the grant of tentative approval by the city. 
(2)  Contents. The preliminary plan shall include: 
a.  Proposed name of subdivision. 
b.  Location by section, township, and range, or by other legal description. 
c.  Names and addresses of the proprietor, and the planner, designer, engineer or surveyor who designed the subdivision layout; the proprietor shall also indicate his or her interest in the land. 
d.  Scale of plan, with one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet as the minimum acceptable scale. 
e.  Date. 
f.  Northpoint. 
(3)  Existing conditions. The preliminary plan shall include: 
a.  An overall area map at a scale of not less than one (1) inch equals two thousand (2,000) feet showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings such as section lines and/or major streets or collector streets shall be provided. 
b.  Boundary line of proposed subdivision, section or corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract and overall property dimensions. 
c.  Property lines of adjacent tracts of subdivided and unsubdivided land shown in relation to the tract being proposed for subdivision including those of areas across abutting roads. 
d.  Location, widths and names of existing or prior approved streets and private streets, and public easements within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision, including those located across abutting roads. 
e.  Location of existing sewers, water mains, storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision. 
f.  Topography drawn as contours with an interval of at least two (2) feet. Topography shall be based on United States Geological Survey datum. 
g.  The school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned shall be informed and made aware of the preliminary plan by the proprietor. A letter or document from the school board or school board superintendent indicating awareness of the proprietor's intentions shall be submitted to the planning commission as part of the preliminary plan. 
(4)  Proposed conditions. The preliminary plan shall include: 
a.  Layout of streets indicating proposed street names, right-of-way widths and connections with adjoining approved streets and also the widths and location of alleys, easements and public walkways. 
b.  Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots, including building setback lines showing dimensions. 
c.  Indication of parcels of land intended to be dedicated or set aside for public use or for the use of property owners in the subdivisions. 
d.  An indication of the ownership existing and proposed use of any parcels identified as "excepted" on the preliminary plan. If the proprietor has an interest or owns any parcel so identified as "excepted," the preliminary plan shall indicate how this property could be developed in accordance with the requirements of the existing zoning district in which it is located and with an acceptable relationship to the layout of the proposed preliminary plan. 
e.  An indication of the system proposed for sewage by a method approved by the council and the city engineer. 
f.  An indication of the system proposed for water supply by a method approved by the council and the city engineer. 
g.  An indication of the storm drainage proposed by a method approved by the council and the city engineer and, if involving county drains, the proposed drainage shall be acceptable to the county drain commissioner. 
h.  In the case where the proprietor wishes to subdivide a given area, but wishes to begin with only a portion of the total area, the preliminary plan shall include the proposed general layout for the entire area. The part which is proposed to be subdivided first shall be clearly superimposed upon the overall plan in order to illustrate clearly the method of development which the proprietor intends to follow. Each subsequent plan shall follow the same procedure until the entire area controlled by the proprietor is subdivided. 
i.  If the subdivision is proposed to be developed under planned unit development, such subdivision shall meet the requirements of section 27-60. 
(5)  Review by planning commission: 
a.  The city clerk shall receive and, with such assistance of other city departments and consultants as may be necessary, check for completeness of the preliminary plan as required under subsections (1) through (4). Submittal with the city clerk shall be at least twelve (12) days prior to the next regular planning commission meeting at which the proprietor will be scheduled to appear and the planning commission will consider acceptance of the submission. Should any of the data required in this section be omitted, the city clerk shall notify the proprietor of the additional data required, and planning commission action shall be delayed until the required data is received. If complete and basically in conformance with applicable city requirements, the city clerk shall place the proposal on the agenda of the next regular planning commission meeting to consider tentative approval of the preliminary plan. 
b.  The city clerk shall transmit a copy of the preliminary plan to the city engineer, city planner and city fire marshal for their technical review and recommendation. 
c.  The planning commission shall review all details of the proposed subdivision within the framework of the zoning chapter, within the various elements of the master plan and within the standards of this chapter. 
d.  The planning commission shall tentatively approve and note its approval on the copy of the preliminary plan, or tentatively approve it subject to conditions and note its approval and conditions on each copy of the preliminary plan, or set forth in writing its reasons for rejection and requirements for tentative approval, within the following time period, as applicable, unless the proprietor agrees to an extension of time in writing: 
1.  Within sixty (60) days after it was submitted to the clerk, if a pre-application review meeting was conducted under subsection 27-37(c). 
2.  Within ninety (90) days after it was submitted to the clerk, if a pre-application review meeting was not conducted under subsection 27-37(c). 
e.  Subject to subsections (6) and (7), below, the chairperson shall distribute copies of the preliminary plan, with a notation of the tentative approval and any conditions on each copy of same, as follows: 
1.  Return one (1) copy to the proprietor; 
2.  Retain one (1) copy which shall become a matter of permanent record in the planning commission files; 
3.  Forward one (1) copy to the school board or school superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned; 
4.  File the remaining copies in the office of the city clerk. 
(6)  Action of planning commission, council. The action of the planning commission shall become the action of the council unless the council shall request a hearing or unless, within ten (10) days after the tentative approval of the preliminary plan or the record of rejection is filed with the city clerk, the proprietor shall file with the clerk a written request for hearing before the council. 
(7)  Hearing; council approval or rejection. Such hearing, if requested, shall be held by the council at its next regular meeting occurring not less than ten (10) days after filing of such request. Following the hearing, the council shall grant tentative approval of or reject the preliminary plan in accordance with state law and this chapter. 
(8)  Rights conferred by tentative approval. Subject to any applicable conditions of the approval, tentative approval of the preliminary plan confers upon the proprietor, for a period of one (1) year from the approval date, approval of lot sizes, lot orientation, and street layout, and application of the then-current subdivision regulations. The tentative approval may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the planning commission in writing. 
(Code 1981, § 61.130; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 2, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-3-2006, § 2, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 27-39. - Same-Final approval. 
    The procedure for the preparation and review of a preliminary plan for final approval is as follows: 
(1)  The proprietor shall file a valid preliminary plan with the city clerk together with a list certifying all the authorities required by the Subdivision Act and, if any, by the Condominium Act to review the preliminary plan. The proprietor shall also provide approved copies of the preliminary plan from each of the required authorities. 
(2)  The council, after receipt of all necessary approved copies of the approved preliminary plan, shall consider and review the preliminary plan at its next regular meeting or within twenty (20) days of the date of submission. 
(3)  If the preliminary plan conforms substantially to the tentatively approved preliminary plan and meets all conditions laid down for tentative approval, the council shall give final approval to the preliminary plan. 
(4)  The city clerk shall promptly notify the proprietor of approval or rejection in writing; if rejected, reasons shall be given. 
(5)  Final approval of the preliminary plan confers upon the proprietor for a period of two (2) years from the date of final approval the conditional right that the general terms and conditions under which preliminary plan approval was granted will not be changed. The two-year period may be extended if applied for by the proprietor and granted by the council in writing. Written notice of the extension shall be sent by the city clerk to the other approving authorities. 
(6)  No installation or construction of any improvements shall be made before the preliminary plan has received final approval of the council, engineering plans have been approved by the city engineer, and any deposits required under Article IV of this chapter have been received by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 61.140; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 2, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-3-2006, § 2, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 27-40. - Final plan. 
    The procedure for preparation and review of a final plan shall be as follows: 
(1)  Preparation: 
a.  The final plan shall comply with the provisions of state law. 
b.  The final plan shall conform substantially to the preliminary plan as approved and it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plan which the proprietor proposes to record and develop at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to this chapter. 
(2)  Review: 
a.  One (1) true copy of the final plan shall be filed by the proprietor with the city clerk, along with such sums of money or financial security as the council may require to be deposited to guarantee completion of improvements under this Code. The true copy of the final plan shall include all information, certificates and sworn certifications and statements required under applicable state law, including without limitation the Subdivision Act and the Condominium Act. 
b.  The final plan shall be reviewed by the city engineer as to compliance with the approved preliminary plan and plans for utilities and other improvements. 
c.  The engineer shall notify the council of his or her recommendation for either approval or rejection of the final plan. 
d.  At its next regular meeting, or at a meeting called within twenty (20) days after the date of receiving the required filing under this section, the council shall review all recommendations and take action on the final plan. 
e.  Upon the approval of the final plan by the council, the subsequent approvals shall follow the procedure set forth in state law. 
f.  The city clerk shall record all proceedings in the minutes of the meeting and forward a copy of the minutes to the clerk of the county plat board. 
(Code 1981, § 61.150; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 2, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-3-2006, § 2, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 27-41. - Recording prohibited prior to approval. 
    No plan or master deed may be recorded with the register of deeds until it has received final plan approval by council and all conditions imposed by council have been satisfied. 
(Ord. No. C-1-97, § 2, 1-13-97) 
Secs. 27-42-27-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN LAYOUT STANDARDS 

Sec. 27-56. - Generally. 
    The subdivision design layout standards set forth under this article are development guides for the assistance of the proprietor. All final plans must be reviewed and approved by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 61.200) 
Sec. 27-57. - Streets. 
    Streets shall conform to at least all minimum requirements of the general specifications and typical cross-sections as set forth below and other conditions set forth by the council: 
(1)  Location and arrangement: 
a.  The proposed subdivision shall conform to the various elements of the master plan and shall be considered in relation to the existing and planned major thoroughfares and collector streets, and such part shall be platted in the location and the width indicated on such plan. 
b.  The street layout shall provide for continuation of collector streets in the adjoining subdivisions or of the proper projection of streets when adjoining property is not subdivided; or conform to a plan for a neighborhood unit drawn up and adopted by the planning commission. 
c.  The street layout shall provide for connections of roads to adjacent subdivisions in appropriate locations and the streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic shall be discouraged. 
d.  If a proposed subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the planning commission may require marginal access streets, reverse frontage or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation and reduction of traffic hazards. 
e.  If a proposed subdivision borders or contains a railroad, expressway or other limited-access highway right-of-way, the planning commission may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land such as for parks in residential districts. Such distances shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for approach grades to future grade separation. 
f.  Half streets shall be prohibited, except where absolutely essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of this chapter, and where the planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is developed. Wherever there exists adjacent to the tract to be subdivided a dedicated or platted and recorded half street, the other half shall be platted. 
(2)  Right-of-way widths. Streets right-of-way widths shall conform to at least the following minimum requirements: 
Street type Right-of-way width 
(feet) a. Major and secondary thoroughfares 120 or in conformance with the thoroughfare plan of the city b. Primary collector streets 86 c. Industrial service streets 60 d. Multiple-family residential streets where platted 60 e. Minor (single-family residential streets) 60 f. Minor residential streets located within planned residential developments or cluster option developments may have 50 foot right-of-way, subject to approval of the site plan g. Marginal access streets 50 h. Turnaround (loop) street 120 i. Alley 20 j. Cul-de-sac streets Turnarounds: 1. Industrial 75-foot radius 2. Residential and others 60-foot radius 3.  Cul-de-sacs located within planned residential developments or cluster option developments may provide 55-foot radius subject to approval of the site plan. k. Maximum length for residential cul-de-sac streets shall generally be six hundred (600) feet. Maximum length for industrial and other cul-de-sac streets may exceed six hundred (600) feet subject to the approval of the planning commission.  
(3)  Street grades. For adequate drainage, the minimum street grade shall meet the requirements of the engineering division. 
(4)  Street geometrics. Standards for maximum and minimum street grades, vertical and horizontal street curves and sigh distances shall be provided as required by the engineering division. 
(5)  Street intersections. Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible to ninety (90) degrees. 
(6)  Grading and centerline gradients. Grading and centerline gradients shall be per plans and profiles approved by the city engineer. 
(7)  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet shall be avoided. 
(8)  Acceleration-deceleration lanes. Streets which intersect with major or secondary thoroughfares shall be provided with paved acceleration and deceleration lanes and passing lanes on both sides of the thoroughfare. Such lanes shall be provided in keeping with the plan for this type of improvement as shown in subsection (9) below. 
(9)  Street approach to existing highway. 

(Code 1981, § 61.210; Ord. No. C-9-87, § 1, 2-17-87; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 3, 1-13-97) 
Sec. 27-58. - Blocks. 
    Blocks within subdivisions shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Size. 
a.  Maximum length for blocks shall not exceed one thousand four hundred (1,400) feet in length, except where, in the opinion of the planning commission, conditions may justify a greater distance. 
b.  Widths of blocks shall be determined by the condition of the layout and shall be suited to the intended layout. 
(2)  Public walkways. 
a.  Location of public walkways or crosswalks may be required by the planning commission to obtain satisfactory pedestrian access to public or private facilities such as, but not limited to, schools, parks and shopping areas. 
b.  Widths of public walkways shall be at least twelve (12) feet and shall be in the nature of an easement for this purpose. 
(3)  Easements. 
a.  Location of utility line easements shall be provided along the rear or side lot lines as necessary for utility lines. Easements shall give access to every lot, park or public grounds. Such easements shall be a total of not less than twelve (12) feet wide, six (6) feet from each parcel. 
b.  Recommendations on the proposed layout of telephone and electric company easements should be sought from all of the utility companies serving the area. It shall be the responsibility of the proprietor to submit copies of the preliminary plat to all appropriate public utility agencies. Utility layout shall be subject to review and approval by the engineering division. 
c.  Easements three (3) feet in width shall be provided where needed along side lot lines so as to provide for streetlight dropouts. Prior to the approval of the final plat for a proposed subdivision, a statement shall be obtained from the appropriate public utility indicating that easements have been provided along specific lots. A notation shall be made on the final plat indicating: "The side lot lines between lots (indicate lot numbers) are subject to streetlight dropout rights granted to the (name of utility company)." 
(Code 1981, § 61.220) 
Sec. 27-59. - Lots. 
    Lots within a subdivision shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Size and shape: 
a.  The lot size, width, depth, and shape in any subdivision proposed for residential uses shall be appropriate for the location and the type of development contemplated. 
b.  Lot areas and widths shall conform to at least the minimum requirements of the zoning ordinance for the district in which the subdivision is proposed. 
c.  Building setback lines shall conform to at least the minimum requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
d.  Corner lots in residential subdivisions shall be planned at least ten (10) feet wider than the minimum width permitted by the zoning ordinance. 
e.  Excessive lot depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A depth-to-width ratio of three to one (3:1) shall normally be considered a maximum. 
f.  Lots intended for purposes other than residential use shall be specifically designed for such purposes, and shall have adequate provision for off-street parking, setbacks and other requirements in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Arrangement: 
a.  Every lot shall front or abut on a street. 
b.  Generally, side lot lines shall be at right angles or radial to the street lines. 
c.  Residential lots abutting major thoroughfares or collector streets, where marginal access streets are to desirable or possible to attain, shall be planned with reverse frontage lots, or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic streets, or shall be planned with extra depth to permit generous distance between building and such trafficway. 
d.  Generally, lots shall have a front-to-front relationship across all streets where possible. 
e.  Where lots border upon bodies of water, the front yard may be designated as the waterfront side of such lot provided the lot has sufficient depth to provide adequate setback on the street side to maintain a setback for all structures equal to the front setback on the street side as well as on the waterfront side. 
(Code 1981, § 61.230; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 3, 1-13-97) 
Sec. 27-60. - Subdivision open space plan. 
    The following requirements apply in addition to all other requirements of this chapter where a preliminary plan is filed for approval under the subdivision open space plan section of the zoning chapter: 
(1)  Statement of principles. The subdivision open space plan section of the zoning chapter provides an optional method of subdividing property. Consideration by the planning commission and the council of subdivision open space plans shall reflect the following basic principles: 
(a)  Particular attention shall be given to the effect of a subdivision open space plan upon the immediate area, where the character of that area has been established by previous development, including the compatibility of the proposed plan with the existing lot areas and widths in the surrounding area. Major attention shall be given by the planning commission and the council to the benefits to be derived by the residents of the proposed subdivision and the city because of the subdivision open space plan with minor consideration to be given to the proprietor. 
(b)  The following objectives set forth in the city zoning chapter shall govern the approval or disapproval of the proposed subdivision open space plan. 
1.  To encourage a more desirable living environment by preserving the natural character of wetlands, stands of trees, brooks, hills, and similar natural assets; 
2.  To encourage developers to use a more creative approach in the development of residential areas; 
3.  To encourage the provision of open space within reasonable distance of all lot development so benefits may accrue to the subdivision and to further encourage the development of recreational facilities and areas or the preservation of natural environment assets; 
4.  To encourage a more efficient, aesthetic, and desirable use of the land while recognizing a reduction in development costs and by allowing the developer to bypass natural obstacles on the site. 
(2)  Parcels for common use. A parcel to be dedicated for the common use of the subdivision shall be in no instance less than two (2) acres and shall be in a location and shape approved by the city; provided, that a parcel divided by a road or stream shall be considered as one parcel. 
(3)  Application; contents. The application for approval of a subdivision open space plan shall contain the following in addition to the information required by other sections of this chapter. 
(a)  The planner shall review and render an opinion upon the proposed subdivision open space plan from the materials furnished and from visits to the site or such other information as may be deemed necessary and render an opinion with respect to the following: 
1.  The effect upon neighboring areas which would result by the subdivision open space plan and the compatibility of the development of the lot sizes proposed under the subdivision open space plan in relation to the surrounding area; 
2.  The location and layout of the reduced lot sizes in relation to the existing lot sizes in the surrounding area; 
3.  The suitability of the proposed open land for purposes proposed; 
4.  The need for the proposed uses in the general area; 
5.  The location and layout of the open spaces with relation to the lots within the subdivision; 
6.  Any other factor related to the development and proper design of the proposed subdivision. 
(b)  The city attorney shall review the proposed subdivision open space plan and render an opinion with respect to the following: 
1.  The proposed manner of holding title to the open land; 
2.  The proposed manner of payment of taxes; 
3.  The proposed method of regulating the use of the open land; 
4.  The proposed method of maintenance of property and financing thereof; 
5.  Any other factor related to the legal or practical problems of ownership, use, and maintenance of the open land. 
(4)  Tentative planning commission approval. If the planning commission is satisfied that the proposed subdivision open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning chapter and this chapter and should be approved, it shall give tentative approval to the plan with the conditions upon which such approval should be based. Thereafter, the council shall take action upon such application in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Rejection; request for hearing. If the planning commission is not satisfied that the proposed subdivision open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning chapter or this chapter or finds that the approval of the subdivision open space plan will be detrimental to existing development in the general area and should not be approved, it shall communicate such disapproval to the council with the reasons therefore. The proprietor shall be entitled to a hearing upon such proposal before the council upon written request therefore filed with the city clerk. 
(6)  Preliminary council approval; contract. If the council gives preliminary approval to the proposed subdivision open space plan, it shall instruct the city attorney to prepare a contract setting forth the conditions upon which such approval is based, which contract, after approval thereto by the council, shall be entered into between the city and the proprietor prior to the approval of any final plan based upon the approved preliminary plan. 
(7)  Security deposit. At the time of application for final approval, the proprietor shall deposit cash, irrevocable letters of credit, or other equivalent forms of security as approved by the city attorney in the amount of the estimated cost of the proposed improvements to the open land guaranteeing the completion of such improvements within a time to be set by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 61.240; Ord. No. C-10-86, § 1, 3-7-86; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 3, 1-13-97; Ord. No. C-14-00, § 1, 10-23-00) 
Sec. 27-61. - Natural features. 
    The natural features and character of lands must be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features such as large trees, natural groves, watercourses, and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property, if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the proprietor and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers, where appropriate, shall be required. 
(Code 1981, § 61.250; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 3, 1-13-97) 
Sec. 27-62. - Floodplain. 
    Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by stormwater, shall require specific compliance with the Subdivision Act and its review by the agencies charged with such regulation by state law. 
(Code 1981, § 61.260; Ord. No. C-1-97, § 3, 1-13-97) 
Secs. 27-63-27-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 27-81. - Generally. 
    Improvements shall be provided by the proprietor in accordance with the standards and requirements established in this chapter and/or any other such standards and requirements which may from time to time be established by ordinance or published rules of the city. All improvements must meet the approval of the council. Improvement bonds, cash deposits, maintenance bonds and other similar deposits shall be provided as required by the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 61.310) 
Sec. 27-82. - Streets. 
    All streets and appurtenances thereto shall be constructed in accordance with details and specifications approved by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 61.320) 
Sec. 27-83. - Utilities. 
(a)  Underground wiring.
